⚪ Vampire Survivor: Where Garlic is Your Best Friend (and You Die a Lot, Seriously)

Imagine this: You're a lone survivor armed with a measly whip, surrounded by an endless horde of bloodsuckers with questionable hygiene. This, my friends, is Vampire Survivor, where death is your BFF and garlic is your holy grail.


➡ The Good:

• Simple but Addictive: It's easy to learn, hard to master, and impossible to put down. Think "bullet hell" meets "endless runner" with a dash of "why am I laughing while dying?"
• Power Up Frenzy: Garlic, crosses, spinach, axes...the list goes on! Each upgrade is hilarious and hilariously overpowered. Who knew a clock could be so deadly?
• Death is Just a Suggestion: You'll die. A lot. But each run is different, and the sense of progression is incredibly satisfying. Plus, watching your character explode in a shower of garlic and spinach is oddly therapeutic.
• Price is Right: This game costs less than a pizza and delivers more entertainment than a whole haunted house. Seriously, what are you waiting for?


➡ The Bad (But Not Really Bad):

• Repetitive After a While: The core gameplay loop doesn't change much, but the sheer number of unlockables and challenges keeps things fresh.
• Can Get Grindy: Reaching max level takes some dedication (or a lot of garlic bread). But hey, that's part of the fun, right?
• Story? What Story?: There's no grand narrative, just pure, unadulterated survival against the undead masses. But honestly, who needs a story when you have garlic?
• Cross-Platform Blues: I played this on my phone first, then my PC. Sadly, no cross-platform sign-in, meaning my garlic-fueled progress vanished!


➡ Overall:

Vampire Survivor is a hilarious, addictive, and surprisingly deep experience for the price of a latte. Just be prepared to die a lot, question your sanity, and become strangely obsessed with garlic.


⦿ Would recommend to: Anyone who enjoys fast-paced action, doesn't mind a little (or a lot) of death, and has a healthy appreciation for garlic-fueled mayhem.

⦿ Would NOT recommend to: People with anger management issues, those who prefer their games with a side of sunshine and rainbows, and anyone who is allergic to garlic (or vampires).

‣ P.S. Don't underestimate the power of the clock. It's a game-changer. And seriously, watch out for the Reaper. He's not here to party.

‣ P.P.S. Devs, please hear our pleas! Add cross-platform sign-in, and we'll be eternally grateful (and garlic-powered)!

[h1] Overall [/h1]
10/10: A really satisfying arcade-style game. Great game to play while listening to podcasts or music. 

[h2] Gameplay [/h2] 
Arcade-style gameplay: replay levels to try to do better and better. You earn gold to spend on permanent power ups to help you survive longer in the next stage. Your character auto-attacks, so you really only need directional movement and then confirming choices of power-ups when you level up. 

I could see folks getting bored with this gameplay, but I think this game is really useful if you want to listen to audiobooks or podcasts while playing a game.

[h2] Story [/h2]
There's no real story. You just try to survive each level as long as you can.

[h2] Graphics [/h2]
Pixel graphics but with great effects

[h2] Music [/h2]
Good music, but I think after a while you would want want to listen to your own music while playing.

This game was my first [b]real[/b] experience in its genre, that being... a rougelike bullet hell survival game, I guess? The music is [i]amazing[/i], the weapon combos are overpowered as hell, the characters are cool with no dialogue and little-to-no story (especially the ones from Legacy of the Moonspell), and the effects some of the attacks make are insane. The lore was a bit hard to grasp for me, but it's a minor part of the game and isn't really the main selling point. There's much more offered here than just a mindless point-and-shoot game to kill time with. If you think you'll enjoy it from the trailers and have a lot of time to waste, try it out.

TL;DR: Good game, awesome music, cool characters, and cool weapon effects.

A Journey to Vampire Survivors

I didn't know about this game at first. I didn't know when it was released on year 2022 after it got developed in 2021 -which the demo available on itch.io. After got married and got children, I became mobile phone gamer: someone who just actively searching game that can be played quickly in my small spare time, and yet really enjoyable to be considered as "fun" entertainment for me.

At some point in early 2023 I stumbled upon certain genre of game in mobile phone game market: top down shooter with rogue lite elements. I played few games that I considered "Okay", but got annoyed with -of course- mobile phone game model with ads, energy system, and with a lot of games have exact copy of asset and weapons that can be used. It moved me to search similar game with unique asset and not a copy of others.

I found few, and installed a game that I actually enjoyed. It was difficult, but felt different. I went to give rating for the game, but surprised with the bad reviews. Many of them said it is a clone of "vampire survivors". That is the first time I knew about this game. I immediately search about it and found it is available here on Steam. I didn't purchase it that time - because it was around the time vampire survivors got released on mobile.

So, I played it in my phone and it is light enough for my kind-of-old phone. It was a blast. I got a game that easily started, played, and enjoyed in my spare time. I went through all original unlocks and secrets after struggling at first. I am sure time spend playing it in my phone reach hundred hours. After enjoying it in mobile, I decided to buy this game, and later the DLCs. Because I have experience before, it didn't took long to get 100% achievement.

I simply recommend this game for someone who search for a game that could be played in short-time frame, and yet still really enjoyable in the long run.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

READ THE DESCRIPTION BEFORE BUYING IT!

I got this game after watching two of my favourite YT gaming channel videos, but I got very disappointed of what this game actually is. It is in fact a casual game, as casual as Pac-Man and for me that's a bygone era. I'd give the game a like if it'd require more input from the player; there are some maps where you have to walk down the path to grab an item to unlock it, but that's all about. You've got a bunch of characters to choose from, but it doesn't matter which character will you pick, the gameplay is always the same. Basically you've got to get the most OP weapons and then just stay in place and wait for the run to end. I understand it's a causal game, but nobody mentioned it's a part-idler! For 15 minutes let's say you've got to gather gems to get your gear, but once you have it you just wait until you get your goal. Sometimes another 15 minutes, sometimes 45, so go ahead and make yourself scrambled egg and wash the dishes while your game is playing. I don't mind idle games, but this one requires you to check on within the run.

Another thing are DLC's, where each one costs about the same as the base game (£1) and adds only one map and a few characters. Nice trick to milk the money from completionists.

This is the game that's supposed to be the parent of Death Must Die? well, the child has surpassed the parent. The gameplay is literally just walking around. you can't attack when you want to, and you can't disable auto-attack. 

You basically just watch the character kills everyone while all you do is avoid the enemies, which is kinda boring. you also can't direct your attacks. Your character attacks in random directions, and it is really annoying for most of the time. 

The art style and the game's idea are great, but I think that the gameplay and combat system were meh. if you can either disable auto-attack or direct your hits the game would have been much better IMO.

The game the popularized rogue-like shoot 'em-ups. Visuals are pretty mediocre but the game loop (where you explore the map, defeating enemies & collecting upgrades until you're overpowered) is pretty satisfying. To me, it has some similarities to clickers & jrpgs where if you do the right things enough times you can get to a point where you can just coast.

I think it's worth a try (especially since it's a relatively cheap game) to see if you enjoy the game style then check out similar games if you do. It has spawned a bunch of other games in the genre that add various mechanics or tweaks to the formula. From what I've tried, I like Boneraiser Minions (Your minions fight while you run away), Rogue: Genesis (Slay the Spire-like stage progression), Nomad Survival (not very different).
Its very fun and addicting once you figure it out. you can't stop playing!

- **Heart-Pounding Action**: Vampire Survivors takes the bullet hell genre to new heights with its intense, adrenaline-fueled gameplay. From the moment you dive into the fray, you're met with a barrage of projectiles and enemies that keep you on the edge of your seat.

- **Strategic Depth**: While the action may be fast-paced, Vampire Survivors also offers plenty of strategic depth. Players must carefully navigate through waves of enemies, utilizing power-ups and special abilities to survive the onslaught. Every decision matters, making each playthrough a thrilling test of skill and strategy.

- **Gorgeous Visuals**: The game's stunning pixel art style brings its dark and atmospheric world to life. From the haunting landscapes to the intricate character designs, every detail is meticulously crafted, immersing players in a world teeming with danger and intrigue.

- **Varied Gameplay**: With a wide range of characters to choose from, each with their own unique abilities and playstyles, Vampire Survivors offers plenty of variety to keep players coming back for more. Whether you prefer to rain down destruction from afar or get up close and personal with your enemies, there's a playstyle to suit every taste.

- **Endless Replayability**:. No two playthroughs are ever the same, ensuring that every run feels fresh and exciting.

- **Community Engagement**: The developers behind Vampire Survivors are actively engaged with their player base, regularly releasing updates and soliciting feedback to improve the game. This level of community engagement fosters a sense of camaraderie among players and ensures that the game continues to evolve and improve over time.

In summary, Vampire Survivors is a must-play for fans of the bullet hell genre. With its heart-pounding action, strategic depth, gorgeous visuals, varied gameplay, and endless replayability, it's a game that will keep you coming back for more time and time again.

Vampire Survivors demonstrates an innovative take on the roguelike genre, but does incredibly little with it, to such a degree that the resulting product is monotonous and dull at worst, and serviceable at best.

No element of the game, in any given run, is unique enough from the others of its kind to provide any functional difference in gameplay from run to run in virtually any circumstance. With a handful of exceptions, every map, playable character, enemy, and even item or statistic is functionally comparable to one another to such an extreme that they may as well be identical. The content in this game does not quite feel cloned, but it does lack any semblance of individuality, meaning that two runs played on separate stages with separate characters and completely separate builds will both come across and functionally operate as completely the same. There is no creative decision-making or problem-solving to be done.

To me and to many others aware of these shortcomings, this is still a very fun video game. There is something inherently satisfying about watching waves upon waves of enemies get obliterated without lifting a finger, and reaching the threshold in any given run where you become unstoppable. If this simple enjoyment is enough for you to disregard the repetitive tedium of the gameplay loop, or if you have no priority on unlocks in general, then you will probably like Vampire Survivors. It is easy to learn and requires little attention. This praise comes hand-in-hand with recognizing its surface level gameplay. 

The concept of merging the genres of idler and roguelike is genuinely worth exploring - what is unfortunate is that Vampire Survivors seems more intent to demonstrate and glorify it than undergo any such exploration. You might forget you’re playing a “roguelike,” the only element of the game that is random (and also the only element within the player’s control) are the weapons offered with each level-up. As aforementioned, your choice in items will have so little bearing on the outcome of your run that they may as well also simply be handed to you.

The developer team is devoted to continually providing new updates to the game, hopefully they are eventually able to properly expand upon the concept and add more to the game than additional functionally identical items and stages, which has been the case for several (paid) updates. Vampire Survivors can be additionally commended for its music, and humor.

First of all, this is not really a bad game. My negative review isn't about that and would honestly be more in the "meh" category. This review is strictly personal opinion.

With the disclaimer out of the way... While I am all for roguelike games, this just did not scratch that itch in the slightest. The loop is simple enough to master, and once you figure out what you like to use the most, you just end up spending the rest of the time unlocking weapon combos/characters etc.

So, why did I buy it and not just immediately ask for a refund once I realized I wasn't really having fun? The ratings for one, this is a lot of people's favorite game/style of game. Also, saw a bunch of Youtubers with gameplay videos and they just sounded like they were having so much fun... Also of course cost.

Maybe I would have more fun if it didn't feel so time-gated? Or if the upgrades (aside from character passives) felt like they really made a difference, looking at you To The Core. Not that collectively you don't get more powerful, it's all just really RNG based until you figure out the loop and can start farming chests.

In conclusion, not a bad game, but not one that I would recommend to anyone like-minded. Cheers!

[h2]Surviving the Night: A Gripping Dive into Vampire Survivors[/h2]

In the ever-expanding world of indie gaming, one title has recently made it to my Favories list. Developed by Poncle, "Vampire Survivors" thrusts you into a perilous realm where you must navigate the darkness as survivors of vampire attacks. With its dynamic gameplay and haunting atmosphere, this game beckons to those seeking a pulse-pounding thrill ride.

[h3]Embracing the Perilous Dark[/h3]

From the moment you step into the world of "Vampire Survivors," you are enveloped by a sense of impending doom. Procedurally generated levels ensure that each playthrough is a fresh, unpredictable journey through shadowy dungeons and haunted landscapes. The art style, dripping with gothic allure, immerses you in a macabre world teeming with danger and despair, while the haunting soundtrack sets the stage for heart-pounding encounters.

[h3]Strategizing for Survival[/h3]

Unlike traditional vampire tales, in "Vampire Survivors," you take on the role of a resilient survivor determined to outsmart their undead adversaries. Armed with an array of weapons and abilities, you must carefully manage your items and plan your tactics to withstand waves of bloodthirsty foes. Weapons and passives can be combined and evolved, requiring you to pick upgrades that fit the stage and your build, adding depth to the strategic gameplay.

[h3]The Dance of Endurance[/h3]

Combat in "Vampire Survivors" is a heart-pounding dance of endurance, where split-second decisions can mean the difference between life and death. Navigate treacherous terrain, dodging traps and ambushes while engaging in intense battles with hordes of enemies. The pace is relentless, the stakes are high, and only the most skilled and determined will emerge victorious.

[h3]The Addictive Cycle of Adventure[/h3]

What truly sets "Vampire Survivors" apart is its addictive nature. Each session draws you deeper into its gripping gameplay, urging you to embark on one more run to conquer the darkness. With its challenging difficulty and endless variety, "Vampire Survivors" keeps you hooked, offering a thrilling escape into the night - or until the morning dawns, should you not check the time every now and then.

 [h3]Conclusion: A Thrilling Descent into Darkness[/h3]

In conclusion, "Vampire Survivors" is a tour de force of indie game design, offering a gripping blend of action, strategy, and relentless challenge. With its addictive gameplay, haunting atmosphere, and endless replayability, this game is sure to captivate you for hours on end. So gather your wits, steel your nerves, and prepare to embark on an unforgettable journey into the heart of darkness. The night awaits, and only the strongest will survive.

When I was a wee lad preparing to enter the adult world I was rather hesitant, the world was a big place and I wanted to cave out my own piece. Observing my hesitancy to choose a career, my mom said "son, don't care what people think, follow your dreams and be happy".  Thus I set out realize my dream to become a helicopter anthropologist. 30 minutes into my application my friend recommended Vampire Survivors to me.

I can say that in the 53.5 hours playing this game I have since gained a lot of perspective - I was weak and lacked ambition and that level 80 is just a number. I also no longer fear death, but simultaneously respect that super death is a natural part of the life in the afterlife.

Thanks to the folks @Poncle for helping me turn my life around with Vampire Survivors!

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Vampire Survivors initially captivated me with its challenging gameplay, drawing me in with the promise of difficulty and intensity. I stumbled upon it after watching Asmongold struggle through it, and I was hooked by the sheer challenge.

For a while, the game lived up to its reputation, providing a satisfyingly tough experience that justified every penny spent. I relished the endgame battles, especially the epic showdowns with Death every 30 minutes, a feat I accomplished with Leda just like Asmongold did in his video.

However, revisiting the game left me feeling uninspired. While updates introduced some welcome improvements, such as upgrades for the clock lancet and laurel, they also unbalanced the game dynamics. The once intriguing Arcana mechanic lost its charm with the addition of scaling, tipping the scales too heavily in favor of the player.

As I reached god-like levels of power in the endgame, the thrill of replayability vanished, leaving me with a sense of closure rather than anticipation. While my review may lean towards the negative, it's worth noting that I did spend 200 hours in the game, which speaks to its initial appeal. Despite its flaws, Vampire Survivors still holds a special place in my gaming library.

Vampire Survivors is one of those games that strikes a chord that resonates with nostalgic arcade style of the past, with a satisfying gameplay loop that creates hours of fun for those that enjoy the rogue-lite style with tons on unlocks to keep you playing, all in all if you are willing to give it a chance for the honestly more than reasonable price its worth every penny.

This game is dumb fun, and for $3, it's one heck of a deal. It's flashy, it's simple to pick up and play, has a decent sense of progression, and the luck based power up system is alluring. Coupled with catchy music and tons of unlocks, and the dollar to playtime is unbeatable! The production quality is also surprisingly nice.

Pros:
-Very affordable
-Tons of unlocks
-Catchy music
-Nice sound effects

Cons
-enemies play exactly the same
-Visuals can obscure the screen
-Adventures Mode seems like an unnecessary game within a game mechanic, despite added story.

Gameplay wise, it's a topdown action game where you defeat enemies to get EXP in order to level up your weapons. There's a time limit, and you have to survive for that long in order to clear the stage. Your character attacks automatically. Every time you level up, the game gives your 3-5 random choices to level up, whether it be a new weapon, a weapon upgrade, or new passives. You can "evolve" weapons if you have the right combination of weapon and passives and it's such a blast trying to strategize what build or weapon to go for depending on the choices you get. it's that sort of "gambling" element that makes it addicting at times. You'll always remember that one perfect run where you get everything you need. Then, you get a really bad match, you curse the RNG, and retry again, hoping to get a better shot at it. There are special mobs which drop chests and are extremely helpful, and they're the only way to fully upgrade a weapon.

Most of the enemies will always go towards you. Some will have projectiles but their main form of attack is to simply touch you.

The game is meant to be replayed over and over, and contains a Power Up menu that let's you buy permanent in-game upgrades. They make a huge difference. From moving faster, to getting more EXP, to regenerating health, it makes you feel stronger and better, enticing you to keep playing the game. In the game are also Relics. These add additional gameplay or QoL elements such as endless mode, picking the stage music, shorter stage timer, and my favorite: Aracana mode. This one adds a bunch of goofy gimmicks and gameplay elements that completely change the game. Game Killer and Suor Clerici. That's all I'm going to say.

Story wise, there's not much to it. You're a survivor in search of a vampire. The Bestiary and stage description reveal bits of lore and world building but nothing too solid. Adventure Mode also provides some character motivations and expands what the Bestiary already says.

But the game does get a bit boring after awhile after realizing there's not much to it beyond the exciting visuals and sounds.

Each character has their own unique starting weapon and different passives. Some are faster, others are tankier.  But overall, every character feels more or less the same, barring a few, with very weird gimmicks or large hitboxes. 

As you play through the game, you'll unlock more stages. They vary from difficulty, and the difficulty isn't linear. Sometimes, the stage you unlock will be easier than the previous one. One stage will have deliberate enemy mixups that make you think on your feet, countering defensive players, while also forcing offensive players to rely on some sort of survivability.  Other times, the stage will be an absolute breeze for the next 20 minutes, then it floods you with incredibly tanky monsters.

And all of this asskicking wouldn't be complete without kickass music. I'm not a musician, but they're catchy, straightforward, and get stuck in your head. My favorites are Red and Blue, Castle People, Moms are Tough, and It's Raining Minotaurs.  There's an okay variety of synthy music, with some DnB and heavy electronic elements. I like that a lot of them sound so 2000s with the MIDI. Some just sound straight up Castlevania. Other tracks sound like homages to other video game series or composers, like Dark Souls (PLIN PLIN PLON) Hatoshi Sakimoto (Final Fantasy Tactics, FF12, and Muramasa The Demon Blade) to even Yoko Shimomura (Kingdom Hearts, Live A Live). It's all so nerdy, but even if you don't know some of the puns and references, they don't take away from how awesome the music is. Speaking of references-

The game has lots of references to Italian culture. No surprise because it's made by an Italian. It adds a bit of flavor and exoticism imo. As an American anyway! From pop-culture references to dumb puns, it's a tip of the iceberg from another culture. For example, there's a character named, "Poe Racho" which is a pun of the Italian word, "Poveraccio". A poor or trashy person. Another are the names "Belpaese" and "Christine Davain". Bel Paese means, Beautiful Country in Italian, and Christine D'avena is a famous Italian singer. Also, cheese. LOTS of cheese references. Get it? Because it's Italian and players are trying to cheese the game to get the best results possible?

All in all, there are worse ways to spend $3. At worst it's just mental stimulation.; it may not be "fun" but it keeps you occupied and makes you feel something. At best, it's a simple, wonderful game that's a feast for the eyes and ears. Buy this game.

This is a fun, cheap roguelike game that you can easily get sucked into. Play sessions for first time players typically start off slow, but as you progress through the game it gets more challenging, more active and much harder. Sessions typically last about 30 minutes after playing and unlocking things, so it never feels like it drags out too bad. The music is hella good and the action is just super entertaining if you're into rogulikes. It's definitely a good time waster game if you're just looking for something relatively casual to play.

The devs have been working hard to make sure this game stays pretty fresh and fun. A lot of updates involve new characters, wepaons, upgrades, maps, even some mechanics and it just keeps coming. I don't think I've ever found this game becoming stale because of it. The amount of care they put into this game is amazing ESPECIALLY FOR A $5 USD PRICE POINT! You get so much more than what it's actually worth. I've pumped in just over 20 hours on this game and still come back to it a lot of times when i just need something to do!

While you'll find games of the genre that look more polished and offer a great gameplay experience, this game, for some reason, keeps you coming back just to see how silly of weapon combinations you're going to be able to perform. Happiness is in the simple things.

Vampire Survivors, developed by indie developer Poncle, is a minimalist, roguelike survival game that has taken the gaming community by storm with its simple yet addictively challenging gameplay. In this game, players select a character and survive against hordes of supernatural enemies, continuously upgrading their abilities and weapons to withstand the ever-increasing difficulty. 

Gameplay Mechanics
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
The core gameplay of Vampire Survivors is deceptively simple, focusing on movement as players automatically attack incoming waves of enemies. The simplicity of the controls belies the depth of strategy involved, particularly in weapon and power-up selections, character positioning, and timing for using special items. This minimalist approach makes the game accessible to a wide range of players while still offering a challenging experience for those looking to maximize efficiency and reach the later stages of the game.

Progression System
Rating: 8/10 - Good
Vampire Survivors features a progression system that rewards both short-term and long-term play. Throughout each run, players collect experience to level up, choosing upgrades from a randomized selection to enhance their character's abilities. Additionally, the game incorporates a meta-progression system, allowing players to unlock new characters, weapons, and passive enhancements that persist across runs. This system encourages experimentation with different builds and strategies, though it can feel grindy at times as players work to unlock all available options.

Visual and Audio Presentation
Rating: 7/10 - Good
The game's visual presentation is minimalist, featuring pixel-art graphics that pay homage to classic 8-bit and 16-bit games. While the visuals are not groundbreaking, they suit the game's straightforward gameplay and add to its retro charm. The audio, consisting of catchy chiptune tracks and satisfying sound effects, complements the action well, enhancing the overall experience. However, more variety in both visuals and audio could further improve the game's immersive qualities.

Replayability
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
Vampire Survivors excels in replayability, thanks to its randomized progression system, a wide array of unlockable content, and the inherently addictive nature of its gameplay loop. Each run feels distinct, with different weapon and power-up combinations leading to unique playstyles and challenges. The game's difficulty curve and the lure of unlocking new characters and abilities keep players coming back for "just one more run," making it a perfect game for both short bursts and longer play sessions.

Overall Entertainment Value
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
Vampire Survivors offers an exceptional entertainment value, especially considering its status as an indie game. Its simple yet addictive gameplay, combined with a deep progression system and high replayability, ensures that players will spend hours trying to master its challenges. The game's straightforward mechanics make it easy to pick up but hard to put down, striking a perfect balance between accessibility and depth.

Overall Summary and Recommendation:
Vampire Survivors is a standout title in the roguelike genre, offering a refreshingly simple yet deeply engaging gameplay experience. Its success lies in its ability to hook players with its straightforward mechanics, then keep them engaged with its complex progression system and high replayability. 

Highly Recommended for fans of roguelike games and those seeking a challenging yet accessible gaming experience. Vampire Survivors is a testament to the idea that simplicity, coupled with well-designed gameplay mechanics, can lead to a highly rewarding and enjoyable game, promises endless hours of fun and satisfaction with best value for money.

Hotline Miami is a top-down shooter where you use the mouse to aim and time your shots < The Binding of Isaac is a top-down shooter where you use four buttons to shoot in only the cardinal directions < In Vampire survivors, the only controls are movement and selecting from menus.  What?  Maybe good if the baddies have a variety of movement and attack patterns, right?  All the baddies only move directly toward you (except for a few that appear at set times) and all their attacks are they only do damage when you bump into each other.  How the heck could a game be good under that many constraints?  Can you write a great novel using only the letter 'a'?  Answer: "aaaaaaaaaaa.  This game is awesome".
So people only play it because it has some addictive progression mechanisms?  Nope!  This isn't Cookie Clicker.  (I tend toward big-brained games.  I've beaten Factorio solo 5 times and scored 30 consecutive wins in Shenzhen Solitaire, however) Vampire Survivors has a very good amount of depth of strategy (not extreme though) combined with excellently-tuned progression mechanisms.
10/10, would recommend to anyone.. anyone, that is, who is completely immune to addiction.  If you have any propensity to get addicted to anything, this game will eat your life.

It's fantastic for people with disabilities, as it's nice for everyone to be able to play this game. However, there are significantly better games for people out there.

The fact people chose this as their game of the year over something like Elden Ring (Which I hate, by the way) and God of War is completely surprising to me.

This game has popularized the "Bullet Heaven" genre with its wealth of characters and weaponry. Using the same tactics that make gambling addictive in a way that isn't evil and predatory is amazing to see - the game begs you, cajoles you, and powerfully entices you to play just a little more. It also unfolds a bit like an incremental game, adding new mechanics and ways to power-up or challenge you as it goes.

Vampire Survivors with the aesthetic of Path of Exile. Also, you actually have to aim your attacks separately from your movement which I enjoy as it makes the game much more active. Not quite as much content as VS, but to be honest I've played a lot of bullet heaven games and for whatever reason after 100%ing all the greats (VS, Holocure, Death Must Die, etc.) this is the one I find myself returning to the most when I just want to play a quick round or two of a game. Also, its still in development as of the time of this review so there's more game to look forward to!

It will cost you a lot of time if you don't understand the addictive mechanisms it uses to trap you.

[h1]Great game that keeps getting better[/h1]

Didn't think I'd like it, didn't know i'd love it. Was getting sad finishing the main game and found the DLC.

Summary:
It keeps getting better the higher levels you gain and by better I mean a large amount. It's exponential progression and respectful of the time you put into it so if you are pressed on time, this is the one. You will need a strategy guide or tons of trial and error to figure out how to break the game. Look up the strategy guide on steamlists by darkwell is a good place to start, it is a dps focused guide and cleanly laid out.

The highest priority when you first start the game is to farm for gold on the inlaid library map, which is the second map you unlock. Buy the best power ups for the amount of gold you have. Gold for power ups is refundable, so no worries, keep upgrading your selections, then when you make more gold, refund and reinvest, repeat. You will need 10-20k gold roughly for late game to plow through enemies. It doesn't take too long.

The characters you should make a priority to purchase are Imelda then Arca, after that, Mortaccio.

You will need to be good at kiting enemies, very similar to black ops zombies. When you select the right weapon/item combinations in game, you will beat the level and plow through enemies. Once you have enough gold for power ups, are good at kiting, good at weapon/item selection, then you will be able to beat the level over and over and get better scores. Beating the level in this game means you are on a 30min timer, survive the whole 30 and you will see a results screen that shows you your stats. The faster you are at plowing through enemies, the better your results will be. The stats results page gives you a lot of info, I usually screenshot it and compare to my previous runs or other's runs.

The first map will be likely make you feel frustrated, though eager to try over and over. The initial goal is to get rich or die trying, literally. You will need to die many times before you have farmed enough gold from map 1 to be able to plow through enemies nonstop and survive. It doesn't take too long.

---

Pros: 
Everything is done right. It will make you eager to advance to the next levels even if you get frustrated, upgrade your characters and power ups.

Cons:
Initial frustration may discourage you and make you feel like late game isn't going to happen anytime soon and you will need to grind forever. Don't worry, this isn't the case, it will happen much faster if you follow a guide.

Overall:
It has hidden content.
Definitely worth full price.
This is the game. You found it. Have fun

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

I really can't recommend Vampire Survivors enough but I also can't tell you why I'd recommend it. It's awesome and addictive but also dangerous. You play one round and suddenly 8 hours have passed and you should have been working.

There's almost nothing not to love about Vampire Survivors. At first glance, it plays like a super shallow "idle" ARPG where the only thing you have to do is move around while your character automatically attacks. The game deceives you into thinking it will be boring, but then you become absolutely overwhelmed with enemies and start having to approach each run differently to get further and further.

Almost every aspect of this game is made to be incrementally more plentiful as you play. Speed, damage, variety of items you can find, modifiers to those items, variety of playable characters with unique buffs, even the amount of enemies you'll fight. At times, Vampire Survivors will play like a bullet hell, sometimes like an ARPG, and even a Doom/Dynasty Warriors style game where you mow down colossal hordes of enemies. There is an absurd amount of progression and different styles of play. What seems like a simple game at first, eventually becomes deep with an enormous range of builds and ways to tweak those builds.

As for aesthetics, the music is utterly [b]fantastic[/b], and while the art style is pretty basic with limited animations, you'll find that it far more than suffices when you have hundreds of enemies on the screen at once. That being said, the weapon effect animations are about as pleasing to the eye as you could every hope for with such simple pixellated graphics.

At full price, $4.99 USD is a suspiciously low price for the game you're getting. Unless you're on the brink of living on the streets, don't even bother waiting for a sale! The sooner you play this game the sooner it can take over your life.

[b][h1]Vampire Survivors[/h1][/b]I bought Vampire Survivors at a time when I was only just getting into Roguelike/lites and I think it is such a phenomenal gateway drug into the genre. When Vampire Survivors released it was practically a new concept combining the likes of similar games that came before it to create what became known as reverse bullet-hells or bullet heavens as I prefer, where instead of facing an onslaught of projectiles like in the latter genre of bullet hells, you become the bullet hell in that your weapons fire independently of your input and that the enemies must instead make it through your bullets to get to you.

Releasing a game like this that is so simple yet so addicting and easily and quickly updatable, all for an insanely low price releasing at £2.47, inspired a huge variety of developers to dip their hand into this genre and create their own spin on the idea, a lot of which are still expanding to the time of this review as well as new games in the genre releasing almost weekly. Not only did this inspiration help developers in that the concept was so simple to recreate, but players also received a huge influx of cheap and easy to pick-up roguelike/lites. Poncle updated Vampire Survivors weekly to bi-weekly for the better part of a year after it's release, playing during this time was practically like playing a different game each week, updates have slowed down to every few months now but that's down to the immense growth of the game and higher quality of each update with Themed DLC's and more intricate maps.

[b][h2]Gameplay[/h2][/b]In Vampire Survivors, you select a character, select a map and you are into the gameplay within just a couple of clicks. Each character starts with a weapon which fires on its own without your input. By killing enemies you gain exp, you level up and choose up to 6 weapons and passive buff items throughout a run, with the whole goal of becoming strong enough to hold out for 30 minutes against endless hoards of enemies. The game released with 4 characters and only a handful of weapons but now has almost 60 unique characters and over 80 weapons (including each weapons evolution) alongside 20+ passives that you can mix and match throughout your runs. Weapon evolutions are practically super enhanced versions of the base weapon that are gotten from chests after your weapon reaches max level in a run, depending on the passives you pick, no one weapon will act the exact same between multiple runs, with systems in place to let you limit-break your weapons beyond max level, choosing different stats will make for completely different playstyles with the same weapons. You can also choose to limit the number of weapons you can take in a run and super power only your favourites with limit-break.

With that being said, the game is basically infinitely replayable as long as you are having fun. Each character includes a page showing which maps you have beaten with them, and with 17 regular maps that works out to a total of 986 runs you can do if you want to be a completionist.

As of this review there are 18 maps total in the game, including challenge levels, DLC stages and Boss Fights, each play completely differently and have a variety of challenges/achievements, special unlocks and hidden items, all of which can be customised to your own liking with modifiers that can reduce total game time from 30 minutes to 15, speed up movement, increase difficulty, make runs endless and more.

One thing Vampire Survivors gets right that a lot of the games proceeding it do not, is a real sense of progression, While a lot of the maps are similar endless plains with few obstacles, the enemies on the maps get more difficult as you play through making it harder to complete each subsequent map which makes you really have to learn what weapons work with what passives and which combine to create a huge damage zone that enemies cannot enter. All unlocks are tied to maps and achievements which make for an experience where you start with very little when you start the game but as you progress map to map finding secrets, you unlock new in game features that drastically change how the game plays, like all the map modifiers mentioned earlier, mini-maps and a whole lot more.

Now of course this game is a roguelite so there is also a page for meta-progression, you collect coins throughout your runs which allows you to upgrade each individual stat in the game that will apply to any character when you pick them, there are also ways here to increase the difficulty further for those looking for the extra challenge. All of these can be disabled or reset at will outsides of runs.

[b][h2]Achievements (196/196)[/h2][/b]It's impossible to avoid the achievements in Vampire Survivors as all of them are tied to in-game unlocks in some way or another, the majority of them are easily unlocked just by playing with all the different characters and weapons, there are a certain few that require you to find secrets or kill a certain amount of enemies that only spawns in a certain location, but given how big this game has gotten there are countless guides out there detailing all of it.

Given that this game has 2 DLCs now, it is important to mention that they are [u]Both Required[/u] to 100% complete the games achievements, while I am usually apposed to DLCs having achievements, their price is so low at £1.59 each, for handcrafted new maps and a bunch more unique weapons, boss fights etc, that its worth the money on top of the base game.

[b][h2]Music/sound[/h2][/b]The music and sound design in this game is amazing, I mean this game even has it's own Orchestra now. Each map has multiple sound tracks that can play, which leads to the game currently containing 50 music tracks including the DLCs that you can choose from before you start a run, These songs will be sped up and slowed down based on the mode you are playing, basically sounding like different songs altogether.

[b][h2]TL;DR[/h2][/b]This game is a must play if you are into Roguelikes or want to get into the genre, it has tonnes of content and near infinite replayability all for an insanely cheap price.

TL;DR: Lots of fun, tons of unlockable things, learning curve is gentle, easily playable with one hand, lots of replay value, and it's dirt cheap!

You don't control the firing of your weapons, only your characters' movement, which can be a bit strange at first, but adds a lot of depth for me, as weapon cooldown and which combinations of weapons/items you pick can make up for that lack of control.

The first few levels can seem very difficult, especially with just the whip to start with, but keep at it, and remember, you don't have to win to unlock new things; even a failed run can earn you some really useful stuff.  

The art style is fun, and my older machine (Xeon E5-2643 3.5ghz, GTX 1060 mini 6gb, 32gb ram) can run it just fine without any slowdown, even when the screen is completely full of monsters and projectiles.

In my opinion, this game is just about perfect for parents or late night workers; the 30 minute time limit on levels is a perfect bite sized gaming experience, and won't keep you up all night.  Although the "one more run" factor is pretty high!

Try to avoid watching or reading too much about it when first starting out; the game has built in clues, upgrade guides, and other reference stuff to help you out, but half the fun of it is trying new weapon/item/character/level combinations and seeing what you like best.  That said, some things can be a real bear to figure out without help, so it's good there is such a vibrant community for this game.

The value for money on this one is out of this world, and I definitely recommend grabbing the DLCs, as they add a ton to the game.

The castlevania feel of the whole thing is great, as a CV fan will spot lots of references to it, ranging from the subtle to blatant.  The 2d sprite style is also easy on the eyes.  HOWEVER, this is one game where I would take the epilepsy warning very seriously, once you become powerful, some weapons generate a LOT of flashing lights.

As for downsides, some levels feel far harder than others, but with experimentation I've usually been able to find a build that works.  Some of the snowy levels still frustrate me, but that can be a positive thing too, keep me experimenting to find new ways to deal with them.

I know I'm heaping praise on this game, and it may not be for everyone, but it really works well for me, and I think most all folks can get some enjoyment out of it.  I wish it was on the nintendo switch, that would really be awesome!

This game is very addictive. It's strange, because gameplay wise, it's not very complicated. The only controls you have are to move around, and the attacking is done automatically. That doesn't sound very fun, but upon playing the game for a while, it starts to make sense. This game is very arcade-y in nature, giving you about 30 minutes to go in and level up your equipment and watch as the hordes of enemies die and the damage numbers go up. This game also has a plethora of unlocks and achievements, so if thats your thing, this game will deliver constantly. It is also very obviously Castlevania inspired, with many enemies and items being ripped straight from there, and functioning similarly to how they do in those games. For a $5 pricepoint, I think this game is well worth the money and will deliver some good, simple fun for hours.

... i sincerely do not understand this game. it's supposed to be concentrated dopamine, but in my 2 hours of playtime i have yet to survive the first 5 minutes. you survival is entirely dictated by RNG, and if you get bad RNG, tough, try again. 

to make it clear - I WANT TO LIKE THIS GAME. i've bought every DLC and sunk in two hours. i don't have this problem in 20 Minutes Till Dawn or Death Must Die where i get unlucky for 5 minutes straight and die repeatedly. it's being offered for a good price, and from what i see by twitch streams and others experiences it's supposed to be good, but the key to enjoying this game is luck and if you don't have luck i suppose your custom isn't welcome? the soundtrack is good, the visuals are charming. i can't speak to how well it runs because i've never made it past the 5 minute mark.

in case the developer reads this, the one piece of constructive feedback i can offer? i haven't seen any stage past the first one given survival is impossible, but that first stage is hell on my eyes - blind in one eye with failing eyesight,  the visual palette combined with the visual noise makes the game physically painful for me to play. not colourblind but more options to visually customise the game to make it readable would be appreciated. ultrawide support too would be nice. also i have no idea how to open the map, i know one exists in the game but i can't see keybinds in the options menu anywhere.

i'm not going to refund the game - i will continue to play, see if i can get lucky on a run eventually and see what the game offers. will update my recommendation if it changes at any time. maybe one more run and it won't be a miserable experience. and if not? there's always the next run.

So many weapons and powerups that are uniquely different, and the evolution and unlock systems remind me of NES/SNES times when games were full of easter eggs and secrets that you had to figure out through playing. I hope they keep releasing content.

Vampire Survivors is an enigmatic gem that has captivated me in ways I can't fully explain. It's a game that mesmerizes with its simplicity yet hides layers of depth and endless possibilities. Each run feels like a new adventure, with myriad combinations of powers and weapons that can completely change your playstyle.

The game's design is ingeniously straightforward, focusing on survival against hordes of nightmarish creatures. But don't let its apparent simplicity fool you; the strategic depth here is immense. Deciding which power-ups to pick, which character to use, and how to navigate the relentless waves of enemies makes each session unique and exhilarating.

What's truly hypnotic about Vampire Survivors is the game's rhythm. There's something incredibly satisfying and almost meditative about mowing down endless hordes of enemies while progressively becoming more powerful. The game strikes a perfect balance between challenge and empowerment, hooking you in for 'just one more run' that can quickly turn into hours of gameplay.

This game is a wild ride into the heart of roguelike gaming, offering an addictive blend of heart-pounding action and strategic depth. The diverse cast of characters, each with their own unique abilities, adds a layer of excitement and experimentation. The procedurally generated levels keep the gameplay fresh, but sometimes the pixelated chaos can be overwhelming, making those intense moments a bit of a struggle. The responsive controls, however, allow for some seriously slick moves during the heated battles. For newcomers, be prepared for a bit of a learning curve as the game throws a lot at you, but the thrill of mastering each character and conquering the challenges is undeniably rewarding. Despite a few visual hiccups and a tough start for beginners, this hilarious game is a blood-pumping, action-packed adventure that's hard to put down, making it a must-try for roguelike enthusiasts looking for a challenge and a good time.
Funny and entertainig for hours - worth the cash :D

If you are looking for a fun crowd-control RPG with top-down shooter elements to pass the time, this is quite a good choice.  The price is right, and will net you a good 20+ hours of addictive survival as you try to last 30 minutes against increasingly powerful hoards of enemies.  Be tactical with your upgrade choices, or you will very quickly find yourself overwhelmed.  Best part, you don't need a particularly powerful PC to run this beauty.

Lots of unlockables: new characters, better weapons, item fusion combinations, and even arcana cards to completely switch up your playstyle or augment some of your favorite elements.  Many of these upgrades can be enabled/disabled at will in the options menu to further customize your experience.

The major downside is that many of the levels can feel identical as far as progression and power creep: walk around, level up, gain new powerups, while fighting increasingly numerous waves of tougher enemies   But each stage brings its own new unique power ups, enemies, and stage hazards to the table to balance things out.  

If you have no patience for gameplay which feels repetitive and involves basically just walking around (attacking is done automatically), give this one a pass.  But if the premise sounds interesting and you are looking for another low-demand gem to add to your library, have at it.

At first it's like 'Aw man, this is just Diablo but more boring! All I do is walk around and pick up crap!' and then you see the first chest animation and your brain is like 'Okay I get it now, instant dopamine'

20 minutes later you have no idea what the hell is happening on the screen anymore but it doesn't matter. The numbers go up and the colors on the screen increase. Eventually it all ends when an invincible grim reaper collides into you at Mach 10.

And then you do it again.

You realize there are secrets to be found. You realize the grim reaper can be killed. And you do it again, and again, and again, and again, and before you know it there are no more things to upgrade, nor to grind for. No more characters to unlock. No map that hasn't been crawled across in every manner possible. Then you find 'adventure mode', which is essentially a standalone 'gamemode' with minor twists where you grind to unlock all the same characters and powerups again on different maps.

And then you do it again.

Soon I will eventually clear the adventure modes and have nothing left to unlock yet again, no reason to keep playing, staring into a color-filled void as I watch a number go up. How many times will I continue this cycle? When does it end?

And yet despite almost 100 percent clearing everything this game has to offer, I still haven't found a single vampire.

10/10

Vampire survivors is a gem of a game that is absurdly addicting. It starts super slow and weak but gives you a path towards getting stronger and stronger. The more characters unlocked leads to more weapons unlocked which then leads to methods of manipulating the weapons that show up in the run. This type of scaling continues for the whole base game. There even is a way to brute force past challenges with a purchasable stat boosting item. The best DLC was Tides of the Foscari though compared to base game the weapons are OP and will make any base game weapons look bad.

Pros:
-Amazing progression and unlocking system
-Tools to play the game your way
-Time respecting hyper and rush modes that halve run length.
-A good amount of weapon variety and addon item variety

Cons:
-some of the late game things basically require reading the wiki to determine locations of enemies or what level the next part of the "end" lives on.
-the secret characters are OP to the point of making non secret characters redundant outside of picking your starting weapon. Even a 400x egg main character is weaker than most of the secret characters.
-The shop could have used more upgrades not necessarily for character strength but to augment other systems such as the vendor.
-I wish that they used more in map items to unlock the later things rather than it being a simple completion of a level.

Vampire Survivor is more than a game for me—it's the one that pulled me into the wild world of bullet hell games, and we've been inseparable ever since. The insane bullet patterns, the heart-racing challenges, they got me hooked right from the get-go.

I've dabbled in a bunch of bullet hell games afterwards, but none really hold a candle to the love I feel for Vampire Survivor. It's like the OG of the genre, you know? The vibe, the thrill, it's got that special something that keeps me coming back.

Deceptively simple, stunningly addictive, I've lost track of time playing this game and had to rescue things from the oven because of it. While all you do is move around the massive stages and let the auto-shooting kill enemies as damage numbers go up, this is like saying all DaVinci did was put paint on canvas. Choosing the right power-ups to create OP combinations isn't just fun, it's vital to surviving the last 10-minutes of each 30-minute stage, where your feeling of godlike power is put to the test and the free space to move gets smaller and smaller. The most fun I've had without using my higher brain functions and proof you should never go to a casino if this is your jam. Can't believe this is only $8 with DLC. A less ethical developer would have it at $30 and I'd still pay for it.

[h3][b]Some Game Recommendations[/b][/h3]
[b]Similar Experience[/b]
Brotato (Has more compact runs)
20 Minutes Till Dawn (Visually less confusing)
[b]Something Different[/b]
Hades (Boon system similar to this game's build system. More active gameplay.)
Cookie Clicker (Has simple a gameplay that catches you in instant) 
[h3][b]Review[/b][/h3]
Vampire Survivors is basically a roguelite bullet hell game that enemies are the bullets. But it’s not the charming effect of the game. It uses some of the bright and addicting ideas from other games, and shows us all how to create a good game with just game mechanics with minimum effort. I’m saying minimum effort because when you see the visuals and the gameplay aspect of the game you realise how basic and simple these aspects are. At first glance I wasn’t sold into the game, because of the visual aspect. But after playing it once you’ll get addicted to playing it.

The gameplay consists of moving in the basic directions to avoid enemies and combining the randomly given weapons/abilities. It has run based gameplay. Each run you start with the selected character and level. They have 30 minutes for you to successfully complete them, and the levels have some secret areas for you to explore.  From this simple explanation you can guess the attractive part of the game with ease. You have 6 slots for weapons and abilities each. Most of the weapons have a second phase. In order to unlock that phase, you need to combine it with respected ability. The came have quests or you to complete. Completing these quests gives you the feeling of accomplishment but more importantly it gives permanent characters, gifts, or weapons/abilities. So, you have another reason to try the new equipment you obtained. Explore new synergies to create with other combinations. On top of these each unlocked character has their own passive abilities, stats and starting weapons. Furthermore, the game doesn’t stop here, you unlock tarot cards at some point that give good buffs to some weapons. In the end I hope I was able to let you see how many mechanics the game presents to make you play it repeatedly.

The game thematically and visually is homage to some titles. Some of these titles are Castlevania, Bayonetta. In addition, it just added some characters with stereotypes such as knight, ranger and mage and it just revealed the last expansion pack is with a well-known game Among Us. These additions and reminiscence of other games are cherry on the top of a well-prepared game. Last thing I want to praise about the game is there are some meta jokes and meta gameplay tricks that hit you pretty good. There are not much of them, but because of this they’re impactful, and more fun to encounter than most meta game’s that tries the same thing.

Finally, I can easily recommend this game to anyone that tries to see what makes a game playable and spend a good time on it. One of the issues I have with the game is it visually unappealing and visual effects become tiresome at some point, because of the intensity of spells that are seen on screen. Another problem is I know it shouldn’t be a problem but the game doesn’t allow you to take a break. In a way it doesn’t respect your time if you don’t respect that time as well. Each run takes around 30 minutes without using any level modifications, and the rewards the game usually gave you trigger you to play another round.
This game just keeps me coming back for moar

When I bought the game for less than $4 I didn't expect much. This game actually has a lot of content and replay-ability. At the moment there are 18 characters each with their own unique weaponry and passive buffs. Theres an upgrade menu where you spend coins you earn during gameplay to upgrade your characters before starting a stage, giving you a good head start and allowing you to become more powerful. The coins you earn in game are also used to purchase new characters that you've unlocked with a corresponding achievement.

The game starts slow and kind of difficult as you will have no power ups to go into a stage with. The starting characters you are given fire in random directions except for Antonio and Gennaro. You'll want to pick one of these two characters until you progress a little. As the others are very frustrating since you cannot control where the attacks go. You will run around randomly hoping it will kill the mobs blocking you from the EXP Orbs but mostly to no avail.

I would say you could get around 15-30 hours with this game. Completing all the stages, achievements, and unlocking all the characters. Which is excellent considering the price.

The only two things I would of done differently is allowing the player to attack manually or automatically. Sometimes its better to let the mobs get closer so you don't need to run as much to get the orbs. The powerup menu I would of done differently too. If you have enough coins its possible to purchase EVERY powerup. I think making it more methodical and having to choose which ones you want over others would of been better. Making the player really think about which powerups are best for each character they choose. Overall I would give it 5 stars, it's all about fun and multiplying your power. No time gates or pay walls and its actually a finished game.

I'd be an asshole if I didn't recommend this game, like, I don't know why I even continue to play, whenever I say, yep, it's done, I find the game somehow unlock new stages for me and insane challenges that unlock new mechanics and such.

It's one of the few games that gives you the sense of achievement after beating a boss or a stage but instead of most games that gives you that feeling once or twice, the game allow you to re-experience that feeling multiple times.

Despite this game just being bullet-hell and stuff, it's gonna require using your brain to solve puzzles and find the perfect strategy to beat a specific stage with given RNG items, even if you lost, you're not that upset and happy to play more cause what you gain from previous run aid you in the next.

All in all, it's an amazing game, a great time waster, can be played with one hand, amazing on steam deck even, with lots of content that even at 32hrs mark right now, I still have several more hours to go to beat the game completely, and way more to reach 100% achievements.

Vampire Survivors is some simple fun, well worth asking price.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
You use WASD or left click with mouse to move around, while you do that your weapons will attack enemies around you.
Each weapon has its own way of attacking and each character has their own unique stats and special ability, along with a unique starter weapon.

Along with weapons you can also get passive items that increase your damage and other stats, but also when held with certain weapons will upgrade those weapons.
So much fun. Each level starts fine but after a few upgrades you can slay anything in sight. Pure dopamine.

[h1]Vampire Survivors - Las Vegas Meets PC Gaming. 9/10[/h1]

Vampire Survivors is a rogue-like survival game where you kill thousands of monsters in order to become an unstoppable force of weapons and spells. The game is highly addictive, and despite the visuals not looking the finest, it fits the aesthetic that I believe Poncle had in mind.

There is a good progression system, in that by exploring maps and levelling up weaponry, you unlock more maps and weaponry to try out in another run. Weapons and passive abilities can combine to make evolved versions of said weapons, and it's good fun discovering all of the evolution combinations.

The game runs superbly well; I only encountered frame drops about 3 hours into each run, so I would say it has been very well optimised. With a huge amount of content in game to explore,new content being added here and there and a fun gameplay experience, it's a must-buy game at its low cost.

I was surprised by this game. At its surface it looks similar to a cheap mobile game but when you dive in, it literally sucks you in like a black hole! Its very addicting despite being basic in my opinion in terms of game play.

It is pretty much a horde mode type of game where your only input (outside of menus) is moving and selecting upgrades when you level up. There are several levels and characters you can choose from. A lot have to be unlocked and some are surprisingly well hidden if you don't have a guide. Also the OST is really neat but whatever song you start with on a level, it repeats until the match is over. Lastly, there are next to no load screens and between booting up the game and a match is almost instant!

I highly recommend this game! It is cheap (so is the dlc) and very fun! Also to those that are photosensitive, the flashing lights during certain bits of the game can get intense even for me.

Vampire Survivors threads a very delicate needle.  Creating a compelling loop and deep strategy with the simplest controls imaginable sounds like a big ask, but VS manages it beautifully.  I could give this game to my 80 year old arthritic grandmother with confidence that she could manage it.  I could also give this game to my L33T gamer nephew with the knowledge that it may very well take over his life. 

 I've personally poured over 100 hours into this game (most of it on switch), and I could easily pour in 100 more and be glad.

Vampire Survivors perhaps produces more dopamine per minute than any other game I've played.  It works on a deep, lizard-brain level.  The second to second action is engaging without being overtaxing, and the constant pursuit of the right concoction of weapons and upgrades to create a game-shattering build is the video game equivalent of heroin.  Once you understand the synergies that exist in this game, you will come back to it over and over.

At first I was put off by the visuals, but the need for simplicity makes itself obvious once you've got hundreds of things happening on the screen simultaneously.  My PC is grateful.  And VS runs well on everything, even the iOS version.

On top of all of this, the base game (which is all I have experienced so far; I'm adding the DLC to my cart while I write this) is $5! Insane value.  Even if you are certain that you will hate this game, it's worth risking 5 bucks to be sure.  Because by my calculation, video gaming has never achieved a higher ROI than Vampire Survivors.

Recommended at full price.

I plugged a fair few hours into this now and it's extremely addictive. Whilst the game mechanics are pretty simply; you just control where your characters moves, the other other mechanics keep each run fresh. You have to pick up gems that build up your experience, and at each level cap you can pick from a selection or random weapons or powerups. 

The real goal here is to max out your weapons and make sure you have the relevant powerups to evolve your weapons. You can also sometimes combine weapons. In order to expand your inventory of weapons you have unlock new characters. But there is also a lot more. You can unlock special cards that effect game play and level up characters to increase stats. There is also a bunch of hidden characters that can only be unlocked by achieving certain goals (ever tried killing the Grim Reaper that attacks you at the end of each stage?).

I've seen some reviews that say that it's too easy and repetitive. However, if someone has only thrown 3-4 hours into the game and never really pushed themselves on through the different levels, they have not really experienced how hard some of the later levels get. You need to level up you characters and unlock new weapons in order to progress. 

It's dead cheap, addictive and a much deeper a game than you might think. Give it a whirl....those vampires are not going to kill themselves.
