game of the century

[h1]Prologue[/h1]

Once in a while, you stumble unto a video game that just peaks your interest. Wether it be the title, the synopsis or simply the visuals, there is that something that pulls you in. I was just that way when I found this game, innocently browsing the Steam Store. If someone told me I would spend more than 100 hours playing this, I would have laughed. Surely, this game can't be [i]that[/i] engrossing. I boot it up and while curious I was not expecting much, primarily due to the price. One singular dollar for a video game these days sounds like a joke you'd play on your audience. How cheap can the production of a game be that it only costs $1 for you to play? Again, my ignorance and innocence at play. Some may say that it makes me a an eternal sceptic, others that it makes me just likeable. The main screen pops up, and the pixelized figure of a man who could use a little more sunshine stares at me. Eerie but nothing to be afraid of.  I click play and choose Antonio, the man with the whip. Over the course of the following 30 minutes, hordes of classic horror creatures (except bats because bats are just animals that are associated to horror despite being mainly inoffensive to humans with the only exception being when you are turning out to be tinge too curious and getting inside their nests at night with a flashlight a few dozen times too bright for these poor little creatures) such as skeletons, werewolves, dead man walking and of course the ever oh-so-scary smiling ghosts. The mood was set, the cards were played and this game had just revealed it's true colours. Indeed, what I thought was going to be a simple, gentle ride down gimmick valley was instead going to rocket-jump my ride towards the never-ending hordes of pixels that seek to agressively hug my character until my bones are nothing but dust had finally arrived and there was no such thing as brakes, only more and more destruction. I was at the three minute mark and already my character had whipped his way through dozens and dozens of [strike]evil[/strike] bats and skeletons, all yearning for my precious crimson-coloured life juice. All seemed lost as my experience bar barely reached level 9 when I picked up an additionnal weapon. A runic weapon of some sort. A dangerously pointy and ever more destructive square whose edges could cut through even the densest materials of the known universe, perhaps. It's flight was as majestic and unpredictable as the ever-gracious Ostrich, whose legs and sheer mass wouldn't care about your feelings even if you were several feet higher than it was. For this weapon you see, had no concepts of choosing where or why it went the way it went, Perhaps operating on a different plane of existence than my protagonist ? Perhaps it's inherent qualities made it's perks and querks only irrelevent to the greater picture, a weapon designed to destroy the vile entities of the mad forest ? It bounced and bounced again in a arythmic pattern until it's duration ran out and it vanished once more into the darkness, where it would come from again...maybe one day...or a cooldown cycle. My brave hero, unconscious to the great schemes of the Runetracer (the runic weapon), trotted and plotted a brisk walk to the right and left of the fields, swining occasionally his longer-than everage whip into the corpse-enemy that ever seemed so interested into turning my poor Antonio into a much more munchable version of himself. As the combat went on, I saw on the edge of my eye, something I thought could not be. Something, adverse to the natural order of things. Could it be that this game broke the conventions of reality to bring forwards something so horrible that only a brave man with a whip could face ? As the five-minute mark struck it's deep, resonating bell with a macabre tune, a large circle of earth-bound, agressive plant-based enemies rushed on the scene of the horror, forever trapping the daring hero inside a cage of vines and teeth. Left and right, up and down the whip struck, its edges caked in mud. His boots, now covered from toe to heel in viscous earth and blood as the dead and undead threw themselves, past the barrier of plants and unto the singular man trapped within. The struggle went on for what seemed several more minutes, Antonio covered in leaves, twigs and roots, persevered through the chaos. As I saw the ring of death closing ever tighter around my neck, a new abomination had reared it's ugly head and challenged me to a combat of sanity : the one to keep it intact would win, the other would be banished. The monster had skillfully consealed it's true shape, only showing to the mortal eyes of I and Antonio, the shape of a giant, ravenous Mantis. It's bug-eyes glistening with evil intent, it's scythes sharpened and prone to viciously attack at any moment. The duel of fates went on. One blow against the fiend, rending it's legs and heavily wounding it's eldritch form was not enough to stop it's murderous gait. It shrugged off the wounds, apparently driving it ever forwards to search within itself ever more rage and fury to fuel the forges of it's animosity towards the hero, the smoke of it's ire venting from it's frame from the several orifices that failed to be consealed. As the hour seemed lost, the strike of the creature inevitable, one final blow struck the foe where it could not ignore the pain and with a shriek, fell apart, it's shape devoured by the cosmos, turned into nothing more than what it was made of : dust from the stars. Antonio, bruised and battered was victorious. His wounds barely able to close as his life bar was nearly depleted. His vision, a blurry haze of colors, some green, some red, all his senses overloaded. The fiend was gone but it's influence lingered inside his mind, tremors of fear and hatred coursed through his veins like parasites burning his muscles. He picked himself up and struggled to keep himself from falling, the ground, treacherous as ever, had strained his balance to the point of being unable to stand straight anymore. As the air cleared and the visions of the creature vanished, more foes from far into the mist of his tired sight appeared once more. The enemy had been felled, but the greater foe had not said it's last word. Antonio first felt like he had given his all. Truely, what could be worse than the very ground coming seemingly to life to gnaw and bite at him ? The howling and heavy breathing of a wolfish shape came into view. It's fur waving in the wind as it's yellow, piercing eyes broke the monotony of the fog. Antonio gathered it's strength, lifted his whip triumphantly as a Runecaster flew off his chest. For once since the very start of his quest, the magic weapon finally seemed to understand the threat. It flew true, towards the menace, it's edges shining in the uneasy light. The shape's advance seemed to waver, it's confidence in it's wolfish agility and speed ever more in doubt. Could it be ? Could it be that this mindless missile knew that it's end had come ? In a desperate gambit, the wolf reared it's back legs and threw himself upwards, hoping the jump above the adversary, hoping that this [i]thing[/i] would be as dull-witted as it always was. For a second, the air stood still. Antonio's gaze fixated on the missile's trajectory. The wolf's wavy fur seemingly caught inside a time bubble, as the Runetracer missile flew towards it. Impact. The runetracer had hit something. Antonio could tell, it had bounced a final time before it vanished. Something had happened. Upon inspection, it seemed like the missile had hit, not the wolfish fiend, but the very side of a flower bed. The same flower beds that litter the forest, hiding within their neatly arranged boxes something of arbitrary value. Antonio sighed in disbeleif. The wolf sighed a sigh of releif. The hero had learned a valuable lesson today. Don't rely on runetracers to aim at anything, ever.

It's cheap, it runs great on Steam Deck, a session is 30 minutes but you can put your Steam Deck to sleep if you need to stop and you can continue your run when you wake it from sleep. It's my go-to game when I'm at family or whatever waiting for people to get ready. Or in between when I'm bored and want something both mindless and engaging.

Just don't be like me and think "oh, I'll go and win every map with every character". Go and try to achievement hunt, look at the "Unlocks" tab in the game. You'll constantly unlock more characters, weapons, possible unlocks and more by going for the unlocks. The game will get stale at some point if you ignore the unlocks, the unlocks are what keeps it fresh.

It's 5 Euros. I already got 60 hours of gametime out of it. It's not my main game, but it's a "eh, I'll have a quick mindless 30 minute run" game. It's a great game to switch to when you need something simple for a bit. I'm extremely happy to have this on my Steam Deck.

I first played this as the demo from the game makers' site with the original demo score. it's my favorite song now. So when I found that Steam had the full game, of course I bought it for me and my friend who told me about it. Hello  many lost hours of the night! 

One cool thing about this game is that it is self limiting,... at first.  Its just "How Long Can You Survive?" 
It is a dopamine rush with each upgrade you find. In my opinion, the learning by Doing is a great feature of the game.  it doesn't waste time with tutorials, and the weapons are pretty straight forward. the Shock and Awe when you realize it does something Extra is worth the time trudging through the basics.
No Run is ever the same no matter how you planned.  and the Chests, Oh My Gawd! I had a little dance I did each time I found one. 

But it only gets better when you learn what happens if you survive...

It is hard for me to say what I don't like about the game. Mechanics that had me angry at first, had me nodding my head once i realize what was actually happening and revealed that I had a LOT more control than it appeared from the start. Of course no one is happy at dying, but the way I died had me thinking how to avoid it next time so it wasn't a defeat, just a learning point.

So, becuz I'm stubborn and I like what I like, I muted the game music at first because it was different from the demo. But when my friend convinced me to listen to the level soundtracks, It elevated everything. the Music is SO Massively Epic! It is Familiar yet New, It is Holy and Sinister, it is Motivating and  Captivating and puts the fear of Des[aratopm in you and the Promise of Hope just within reach.  I dont' know who wrote this stuff but its becoming my favorite Get Shit Done music! 

I would recommend this game. It is a great gift in my opinion, a great way to spend a half hour, In and out, and totally Sparkle Joy for the brain! LOL  Oddly enough, I can enjoy this game even when I am having a not so awful migraine because the good feeling kinda makes me forget about the pain for a bit.

I can see why this game is popular is insanely addictive, you'll sit down to do one run and next thing you know you've spent 2 and a half hours on the game. In fact the game is so addicting it took me about 13 hours to realize I wasn't having fun.

The game was presented to me as a rouge lite bullet hell, it's not, it's a clicker, were every click takes a half an hour.

 The only time it was fun was the first few runs where I was still figuring things out. After that it quickly becomes repetitive, first to 5-10 minutes you're a mortal and actually have to try. 5-15 you're a superhuman and as long you're focusing on leveling up to out-scale the enemies you're near invincible. 15-25 minutes you're a demigod who can only die if you stop moving for too long. last 20-30 minutes your a god and you can't die even if you try to, you could literally stop playing the game except for the fact auto level ups don't happen till like level 100, so you have to manually level every 10 seconds. Then death kills you, you unlock new stuff which will allow you to unlock other new stuff on your next run.

There are some variations in levels and goals, while refreshing it's still just another click, on the long roads of clicks layed out infront of you before you're allowed to beat the game

I'm pretty sure you can't actually beat the game (kill death) on the first run. Each run is about unlocking new items/characters/levels which will allow you to unlock special weapons which will allow you to beat death. It seams impossible to kill death with any combination of skills and upgrades. You have to go to a few different to unlock special items to kill death. I even tried to kill death without the special items by crafting the perfect build that would heal me and prevent death from ever reaching me, but nope after a couple of minutes of stun locking/freezing death he just teleport on top of you and kills you. Instead you have to have to use the special weapon that freezes death and stops him from teleporting.

If you're just looking to kill time, then there is no game better than this. But as I've got more games than I'll every play I want a game that provides me with a fun or satisfying experience, this game failed at  this more than any game I've played on the past decade so it just wasted my time. Perhaps the most disappointing thing is there's a good bullet hell rouge-lite in there somewhere but it's buried under 72 layers of Progress Quest.
A simple yet effective grind. Addicting to me.

This game is best summed up with the phrase, "Less is More". 
I didn't know what to expect when I first got into this, it was just hella cheap and I was looking for Castlevania clones, but what I found here was a truly original arcade videogame experience. Vampire Survivors does not pretend to be anything greater than what it is and yet it exceeds expectations and readily reminds me with every session, why games are so great. This game somehow melts my negative emotions away.
In the first 30 seconds, I was somewhat annoyed and disappointed that there is no button mashing involved, it's purely a joystick style game... then those 30 seconds elapsed... and then 30 hours elapsed in like a week.
What compelled me to leave a positive review now, with about half the characters and maps unlocked, was the session I just played with my 10 year old cousin. This game is just as fun solo but with local co-op, it is so simple and yet so thrilling. Nothing beats the horde survival format when it comes to gaming with others for me, whether it was Boxhead Zombies or Nazi Zombies with my childhood best friend or Gears of War horde mode with my dad, it has always created the most interesting experience of cooperative gameplay in my esperience. 
If Castlevania and Pac-Man had a child, it would be Vampire Survivors and I'm here for it. Such a great time killer and truly so much fun. Make some Kool-aid, get two controllers and plug in with a buddy to turn a boring evening into a great one with Vampire Survivors!
9/10 - I hope we see more games like this going forward, simple interaction from the player & minimal but clever mechanics combined with a wonderful aesthetic execution of Characters, Weapons, Maps, and Mobs.

I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
How am I supposed to enjoy any other game now?

In the crowded landscape of indie roguelikes, "Vampire Survivors" manages to emerge as a true gem, offering bite-sized brilliance that sinks its fangs into you from the very start. Developed by indie studio Iced Lizard Games, this title seamlessly combines retro aesthetics, strategic depth, and addictive gameplay into a concoction that's as satisfying as it is challenging.

From the pixelated art style reminiscent of classic arcade games to the pulsating chiptune soundtrack, "Vampire Survivors" oozes nostalgia while delivering a fresh and engaging experience. The game's simplicity is its strength, allowing you to dive right in without the need for an extensive tutorial, yet it maintains enough complexity to keep you hooked for hours.

The core mechanics are elegantly straightforward. You, a lone vampire, must survive relentless waves of enemies in procedurally generated levels. The variety of weapons, power-ups, and perks scattered throughout each run ensure that no two playthroughs are alike. The thrill of discovering a powerful new ability or stumbling upon a game-changing item adds an element of unpredictability that keeps the gameplay dynamic and exciting.

The rogue-lite elements shine through with each death, as you're rewarded with in-game currency that can be used to unlock new characters, upgrades, and items. The sense of progression is both tangible and addictive, offering a constant incentive to jump back into the fray and try out different combinations.

The strategic depth in "Vampire Survivors" is surprising, considering its seemingly straightforward premise. Balancing risk and reward becomes an art form as you decide whether to push deeper into the level for greater rewards or retreat to safety. The game's difficulty curve is finely tuned, providing a satisfying challenge that never feels insurmountable.

The cooperative multiplayer option adds another layer of fun to the mix, allowing you to team up with friends for chaotic and laughter-filled sessions. The synergy between different characters and their unique abilities enhances the cooperative experience, turning what could be a solitary pursuit into a social gaming delight.

While "Vampire Survivors" doesn't reinvent the roguelike wheel, it embraces the genre's strengths and delivers a compelling experience that is both accessible and deep. Its addictive gameplay loop, combined with its charming retro aesthetic, makes it a standout title in the indie roguelike scene.

In conclusion, "Vampire Survivors" is a bite-sized roguelike thrill that effortlessly balances simplicity with strategic depth. Whether you're a fan of the genre or a newcomer looking for an accessible entry point, this game is a must-play. Iced Lizard Games has crafted a delightful experience that proves you don't need flashy graphics or complex systems to create a captivating and endlessly enjoyable game. "Vampire Survivors" is a bite-sized triumph in the world of indie gaming.

REVIEW: 9/10 (|||||||||-)  "Lestat would be proud"

HIGHLIGHT: A thrilling, immersive, hard to put down bullet-hell style rouge-like
DOWNSIDE: Say goodbye to your free-time.

If you're like me, you love a good "one more run" style game. Something that will have you red-eyed in the morning at your job. Your co-workers will invariably ask, "Rough night?" and because you're too embarrassed to say you've been on your Steam Deck until 2am and lost track of time playing a video game, you tell them you went out on a binger. 
(Sounds cooler anyway...)

Vampire Survivors has no hint of a story. I'm sure somewhere in there I missed the developers having thrown in some tacked on tale of an overrun castle, and monsters, etc. Truth is, I have been too busy repeatedly playing to even care.

From first boot, you might even hear yourself utter "uh-oh" like I did, because the front end does not properly tell the tale of the gameplay you're about to experience. After selecting the initial character (you can unlock more later) you get thrown right into the mix of the action. You're severely underpowered at first and I found myself thinking "wait... my whip totally sucks". That isn't just a reference to your mom's hand-me-down rusted out Corolla, your initial weapon will get you beat up faster than a 12 year old in his white belted karate gi on the 1st day of school, but that soon changes...

In minutes, all doubts go out the window and you realize you are in for one heck of a good time. 
The sheer amount of enemies on screen had me wondering if my Deck was going to get some lag going. Not a hint of that. Just onscreen madness. It's incredible fun, and if you've played this style of game before (of which there are quite a few) and are fond of the genre, you will likely find this to be the best of the bunch... it's that good.

You will be grinding that left analog stick into powder avoiding all manner of creatures and collecting as many blue gems as you can muster, looking for an often illusive "floor chicken" to boost your health, keeping you in game for just another few minutes.

I completely adore the not so subtle nods to Castelvania in both music and character design. The library specifically conjured up fond memories of the series and I am sure it had to be an inspiration.

This game is likely scribbled on many a seedy bathroom stall wall.
 "For a great time download Vampire Survivors"

This game is basically as addictive as crack for reasons explained later. Gameplay is like:
1) Low effort relaxation because it's an auto-shooter.
2) You mostly just move around to avoid damage, maximize damage dealt, and gather up "xp" dots dropped by monsters as quickly as possible.
3) After doing that for a while you try to pick the most optimal powerup to select next for the situation.
4) Lastly, you try to get "unlocks" for new characters and more power-ups by finding "relics" on the level or fulfilling achievements.
5) Even if you've effectively turned into god and everything that comes within half a screen radius of you now just dies instantly, the game will still kill you with an invincible monster at some point or keep upping the hp/defense of the mobs of monsters until they increasingly land blows on you.

After that, you spend the gold you got during that game on unlocks/powerups for future games.

Basically the "unlocks" is the main addictive reward mechanism in this.

If you're looking for some sort of coherent story, rational worldbuilding, or clever content or something go elsewhere because the game basically makes no sense at all. I can't tell if you're supposed to be vampires, or if you're supposed to be vampire hunters, or where you're supposed to be or what you're trying to accomplish other than "unlocks" in some generic insane world full of mobs of monsters. Basically questions like "who, what, where,. when" and especially "why" don't seem to have answers provided within the game.

But somehow it still seems to make more sense than Brotato.

So some advantages:
1) You're going to die anyway, so if you need to just walk away from the computer and let your character get killed then no big deal. Because of that it's a good thing to play to fill time when you may need to quit any moment.
2) It works well on the steam deck (and probably a bunch of other handhelds and mobiles) so you can do this while waiting in waiting rooms in public if you need.

Disadvantages:
1) Most levels have little to no level design. Some are just big open floors with some random obstacles. Some are more like hallways with walls on two sides of the screen, but overall the procedural generation is rather weak.
2) Ultimately there's not much to do but try to unlock everything. Unlike Hades, for example, there doesn't seem to be any final goal like "kill dracula", but maybe it's there and just not apparent to me yet.
3) Also unlike other games, it's not possible to "win" a level and move on to the next one. You always die, but a new level will be unlocked if you manage to fulfill some achievement before that happens.

Overall though this is good for when you need something that doesn't need to be taken seriously, and i've ended up playing it more than the other two most similar games I've bought recently (Brotato and Shape Shifter Formations).

This is a game where you are little sprite, trying to survive as the screen sends monsters to eat you. There's also local co-op, which I have yet to try, but may be of interest.

Pick up a whip and smack them hard sideways. Or a magic wand that auto aims at the nearest monster with a projectile. Or play as the handsome shirtless man dual wielding his daggers and throwing them in whatever direction he's facing. Or just be an old man with really tight pants and a lot of garlic and stand there to weed out the weaker monsters, before taking a walk when the elites show up.

Or combine multiple weapons, upgrade them, and pick up accessories with passives to create a survivor that can survive for 15~30+ minutes before the end comes.

Explore your options across 190+ unlockables and counting, many of which add a new weapon, character, stage with its own obstacles, feature, or mechanic to change up how the game is played.

The soundtrack is amazing, the unlocks and ways you can build your character keep me coming back for another session and to clear the next unlock or sate some curiosity, and there are settings to make the game more difficult or getting more power to make the game easier.

There's also an Adventure Mode separate from the main game to get a more structured playthrough and some story to go with it.

I tell you this, when I started up this game, I did not ever expect to be scared, confused, feel blessed by the universe, or cry.  By the time of this review, all of those things happened in some form. 

DUDE! 

You're not listening to me. 

I. CRIED! 

Did I mention the soundtrack was amazing?

And while this game isn't for everyone, you may get bored getting too powerful and playing the same way intentionally without a curiosity to try something different, with no interest to adjust the difficulty settings or trying Adventure Mode to keep things fresher. 

The game has kept me pleasantly entertained and even after what appears to the last Steam achievement worth of unlocks, there are things that aren't achievements that I am still curious about and things that give me motivation to keep trying out thematic builds in different scenarios and even coming up with some head canon. I also turn on Endless Mode so that after 15~30 minutes, I can leave a mission on my own terms instead of seeing my little fellow get slain in one way or another.

e.g., a vampire hunter wielding a whip, axe, and daggers. A priest using a book without evolving it, holy water, and a cross. A witch with cats, a magic wand, fire wand, and other magic implements. Or a warrior that enjoys a good melee with his great sword and heavy armor. And intentionally limiting what weapons I pick up (limit break is available) so that it is a thematic build / playthrough instead of "let me just grab every screen clearing weapon and maxing them out".

So yes to recommend. Especially for that price.

Vampire Survivor is one of the most recent innovation in video game history! Sure, it's probably inspired by a phone game that came before it (?), but nonetheless, I do believe it's the first of it's kind on Steam. That genre is one where you can move around and your weapons/skills are cast automatically.

This lead to a game where you can focus on running away from monsters and dodging attacks, while you automatically shoot back at enemies. It's a roguelike, so every games you start, you begin at level 1. At first you're weak, but through various level-up, upgrades, tarot cards and weapon evolutions, you get progressively stronger. The monsters do so as well, of course. Eventually, when you reach the end-game or grind enough, you can absolutely obliterate the whole game, which feels really rewarding.

At the same time, this brings on to the most negative point about this, sometimes it becomes an AFK-fest. If you care too much about how you build your character during a run, you become literally immortal. Some of the characters are so overpowered that you can literally AFK from level 1 as well, looting XP gems from time to time to level up and then go back to AFKing.

I would still highly recommend this game, which now cost $4.99 at full price and is an absolute bargain considering how much content it offers. Many levels, an awesome soundtrack, retro graphics, hundreds of unlocks and much more. It is one of the only games I would ever recommend to buy even at full price!

Vampire Survivors is a Roguelike shoot 'em up game created by Luca Galante. This game will take you to a world full of mysterious creatures and your job as a hunter is to kill them all. The concept of this game is very unique where you will use one character where that character will fight against hundreds or even thousands of creatures in the world of Vampire Survivors.

There is a lot of content provided in this game. Starting from the many characters that can be played, the map is large and endless, and the choice of weapons is very diverse. This makes gamers definitely want to try all the existing combinations and experiment using their own builds to complete each given stage.

The gameplay of this game is centered on the shoot 'em up genre, where you are tasked with killing all the monsters with your weapon. The choice of weapons provided is also very large. From melee and range weapons, to lasers that are ready to destroy all existing monsters. There are also a lot of characters provided. Each character also has its own stats and each stat also has advantages when combined with certain weapons. The map is also unique. There are many maps that you can try and each map has its own uniqueness. Additionally, each map has several unlockable characters, so the progress you make in the game will feel rewarding. Each map is limited to 30 minutes. After the time ends you will be killed by the Reaper. But don't worry, as time goes by, you can change the time limit using Endless mode. While in the game you have two objectives, one to defeat the enemy and two to collect crystals to upgrade your weapons. When the crystal touches a certain number, a random weapon will appear on your screen. Be careful because each weapon has its own use.

The weakness of this game is the weapon aspect. Each character can use all the weapons in the game. This means that characters who have weak stats will be easily replaced by overpowered characters. In my opinion, each character should have their spesific weapon that other characters cannot use. That way, the character has its own uniqueness. Another one is that if you have played this game often and know the movement patterns of each enemy, then this game will be very easy to complete. You'll often have to wait until the stage to end because your character is already overpower. IIt becomes a sometimes tedious waiting game. Another drawback, this game is not suitable for people with epilepsy. Repeatedly flashing lights and attacking sprites that shoot everywhere can make your eyes hurt and even make you nauseous.

The most important aspect of this game is its simple, fast-paced and chaotic gameplay. Great pixel art coupled with great game performance makes this game a lot of fun to enjoy. You will be addicted when you play it. Because it contains Rougelike elements, every time you die, you can restart each map, with a different character and with a different weapon. It's no wonder why many people spend hundreds of hours on this game.

In conclusion, this game is very suitable for casual or hardcore gamers to play. Simple and fast gameplay makes this game very suitable for anyone to enjoy. With specifications that are not too demanding and a very affordable price, this game is worth trying. But remember, this game will take up your time, a lot of your time. And don't forget, this game will get very easy as you progress and will feel a little boring once you've unlocked everything.

Okay, let me be general and frank at first and then ill move to the well cooked steak:

On a standalone review, this game has value for its buck. It is amusing and has different characters to keep you exploring new features or starts. At some point where you have unlocked everything it can become easy, but the developer thought of that with 2 optons. 1 is to unlock enemies becoming harder and the other is to reset the unlocking. Perfect. I can play the game however I like it and nothing stands in my way. You walk around trying different options untill you find the combinations that you like. Ever played they are billions? yeah dont seny you play it for those undead rushes coming for your base and you shooting them all. Well thats what this game is, just remove the tedious boring parts. And all the clicking.

But (and this maybe where the actual review starts) this game may be somewhat of a statement. I grew up with games that worked and are good, so I may be biased, I think this game is a statement to the A list game devolpers out there that you dont need graphics, you dont need in-game markets, you dont need to be pointed to where you need to go, you just need fun. The fact this game manages to do so in a very simple way - mind you, in a way that would be reprehensible in those days - is a lesson to be learned within the current gaming industry: stop focusing on micro transactions, graphics, trailers, hyping before lauch, and focus at least 90% of the budget on the journey of the gamer itself within that game? no? OK....good luck with that.

I do not understand how I've gotten to this point. I bought this game and its DLC on a whim after seeing a streamer I liked play it, and didn't stop until I had collected every character, every item and did every challenge. At first it felt difficult to live for fifteen minutes, but it soon evolved into constant 30 minute affairs ended by Reapers. You know those rare runs in Binding of Isaac where you manage to get so overpowered, you can't see the screen for all the projectiles you shoot? That. That at all times plus infinity. 

The game is very good at making you feel strong and gives you a nice rewarding feeling with each unlock. Plus it's so simple it makes it a perfect podcast or audio book game. I love all the weapons, the Amongus gear always puts a smile on my face because of how ingeniously it was put in. Character sprites are also a treat, there are a lot of good looking enemies too. The DLC maps are fun to wander around in, being actual levels rather then endless plains of fields or bones.

The downsides are few but are there, I've never fallen asleep playing a game before and it happened twice to me here. Because there is less interactivity than a DvD menu, if I didn't have something in the background to engage with I'd drift to sleep. The only other thing is once you hit that point where you can consistently turn every run into an enemies die on spawn and you don't need to move even on inverse mode, it gets very dull. Though this is by choice, you have lots of characters, weapons and items to choose so it's on you for how easy or hard you make it. Regardless you'll still be either spinning in circles, walking forward or stationary. Not very engaging once you've found everything including secrets.

It is a time machine that sends you to the future. As in you'd play so much yo wont realise it's already 5 hours past when you started.
And it is best played in co-op. Too much fun.

[b]Sights & Sounds[/b]
- Pretty simple pixel art. Honestly, when I first bought the game, I thought it looked pretty bad, but it's grown on me over time
- The sound effects, however, are awesome. It's like the dev had a folder of audio files called "dopamine triggers" and used them throughout the game
- The soundtrack is another high point. I love that music is selectable at the outset of a run, too

[b]Story & Vibes[/b]
- Vampire Survivors is unique in its approach to a narrative: there isn't one, but it really seems like there should be one hidden there somewhere. All the pieces are in place--there are interesting looking characters, lore entries in the form of collections, settings and locations in levels, etc--but they don't really add up to a plot or story
- It follows that the vibes are a little hard to figure. All the vaguely fantasy set dressing and absence of a narrative makes you feel more like you're playing with a toy than playing a video game

[b]Playability & Replayability[/b]
- Here it is: the birth of a new subgenre. There are plenty of imitators, but this gameplay loop is the original. You walk around on an infinitely scrolling surface while autofiring your weapons at waves of enemies that fill the screen. You collect items and upgrades for your equipment that help you cope with the growing forces of bad guys
- Eventually, the timer hits the limit specified in level select screen, Death comes out to claim you, and the run ends (...usually)
- Vampire Survivors is packed with secrets, unlockables, and secret unlockables. You'll spend plenty of time looking through the collection and unlock menus to try and figure out how to get everything
- Despite the lack of engagement offered by a gameplay loop like this one, it's highly addicting. It's like rewards and progress are spaced out at optimal intervals to keep you coming back for your next hit. That said, after nearly 40 hours, I feel like I need a break for a bit before coming back to try Adventure Mode and the DLC stuff

[b]Overall Impressions & Performance[/b]
- It always feels weird putting together a review for a game that's become a cultural phenomenon like Vampire Survivors. The word is out already: it's a fun game with broad appeal and a casual learning curve
- I'm just so impressed with how addictive this game is. Poncle has a grasp of dopamine and reward timing that would put a neuroscientist to shame

[b]Final Verdict[/b]
- [b]8/10[/b]. The market for so-called "bullet heavens" is saturated now, but you'd be doing yourself a service not to try the original. Pick it up and see what the fuss is about

I'm not at all captivated by the lackluster experience of Vampire Survivors, a game that fails to distinguish itself in an oversaturated and tired gaming genre. What irks me the most is the blatant lack of originality, with each new game in this tired genre merely rehashing the same tired formula. In an attempt to provide an unbiased review, I'll compare it to established video game standards, exposing its inability to measure up without resorting to copying other games.

Much like a poor imitation of Minecraft, this game clumsily throws players into mundane environments, forcing them to engage in uninspired combat against unimaginative enemies, all while mindlessly collecting orbs for generic experience points. The so-called leveling system presents players with a limited array of dull choices between uninteresting active and passive skills, resulting in a forgettable and unimpressive character build. Succumbing to the mind-numbingly predictable hordes only leads to a swift descent into mediocrity, akin to being devoured by a forgettable and lackluster creature.

One facet that attempts to salvage the game's dismal appeal is a feeble attempt at humor, which falls flat and fails to inject any genuine enjoyment into the overall experience.

On a scale of 1/10: not worth the purchase, even if it came with garlic as a desperate attempt to add some flavor.

I originally got this game due to it's low price and because it looked like a fun game to keep my hands busy and turn my brain off while I watched videos. Turns out this game was extremely addicting and fun due to the nature of it's game play. The pixel art-style isn't anything extraordinary but rather the highlight of this game is it's game play. The game play is quite simple but as you progress you unlock new weapons, passive items, characters, maps, and discover secrets.

The main game play loop doesn't require that much thinking as you try to level your character and weapons without dying to the monsters that spawn endlessly every wave but it's enjoyable as you play different characters on different maps and try different combinations of weapons. The only times I found myself really critically thinking while playing this game was trying to figure out some of the secrets, but there isn't anything super challenging that I couldn't figure out eventually, making it enjoyable to complete everything in this game and discover all there is to it.

As for the end game there isn't really one, there is not content in the game that is extremely difficult that very few players have been able to complete, the only (sort of) end game that exists is over levelling your character via golden eggs. I personally dislike this form of an end game as I don't exactly see the reason for it and at some point due to the random nature of the golden eggs you end up getting too much speed on your character where that character is almost unplayable with golden eggs enabled.

My final thoughts on Vampire Survivors is that I personally recommend this game as I enjoyed it a lot and for the price you pay for the content you get it's very worth it. As for the additional content in the DLCs, I don't think they're a must buy to enjoy the game as just the base game has hours of enjoyable content to discover but for the players who want to discover everything there is to the game or those dying for more Vampire Survivors content then you might consider buying the DLCs. Overall, it's a super fun and addicting game and I look forward to the future content patches and releases for this game.

This is a really fun game and 100%ing it was such a treat - I look forward to continuing to play it and doing cool challenges and such in the future! This game has a HUGE amount of content and the community seems super sweet and helpful. The graphics are really cute and simple but the abilities have amazing effects. It can be cool finding the best combinations of certain things to do the most damage. 

Certain parts of the game that may seem "buggy" are actually quite endearing. If your movement speed is high enough you can actually clip through walls occasionally which allows for some fun transitioning through the maps. The maps feel well thought out, the weapons and passives all feel strong and powerful in their own ways, the win conditions for the game is varying and cool. Late game mechanics like golden eggs allow for some amazingly broken builds.

I bought this game for 1€ on a whim. Best 1€ I've ever spent.

The visuals looks unappealing at first glance, but 
[list]
[*] the amount of content is staggering and steadily growing,
[*] the music is surprisingly catchy,
[*] the gameplay mechanics are much deeper than you might initially realize (though nothing groundbreaking),
[*] the game respects your time - there is a fast mode, starting/leaving a match is lightning quick, animations are short and skippable etc.
[/list]

To be honest, I can think of absolutely nothing negative to say about the game. It would be easily worth 20€, which in my region would be four times the current asking price. The last time I had this much fun for this little money (relatively) was probably with Terraria (which was/is astonishingly cheap and the developers regretted it, but still supply massive free updates to this day) or with Europa Universalis 4 (which has an extremely, [i][b]extremely[/b][/i] high replay value and the developers are moving heaven and earth to monetise it, so far only managing to lessen the replay value).

This is absolute gaming crack. It may have the graphics of a 1980s Commodore 64 or an OG Nintendo game but it has the depth of a much bigger RPG.  Skill trees, upgrades, character unlocks, an achievement board, and a weapons/loot pool that would put COD to shame.  If you want a 5 minute timewaster this is for you.  If you want a compulsively addictive main game its also for you.  When you start the game you have only 2 or 3 Survivors unlocked: you get the rest by completing tasks in the game.  The weapons pool is a bit spartan too: you find extra weapons and modifications around the maps: once you've found them you can use them in subsequent games too.  It will take a few hours of grinding to unlock all of the enhancements by earning gold coins in the game and then using them in the lobby to improve your abilities.  You'll be dying a lot when you first start as your characters only have their base abilities but stick with it: it gets easier.  There's no tutorial, you're just straight in there, the weapons fire automatically by the way: you just need to use the movement keys.  There's a lot of content and about 150 initial challenges to complete (which allow further unlocks), plus a recent Adventures mode which I've hardly played but looks to be a campaign-style mode plus three very cheap DLCs.  If you want hours of gaming for circa £4 then this is for you.  If you're tired of the Blizzard/EA loot-boxes/pay to win and eye wateringly expensive cosmetics then this is also for you.

Vampire Survivors has truly captivated my gaming experience with its unique blend of intense action, strategic gameplay, and an addictively challenging atmosphere. From the moment I entered the world of Vampire Survivors, I was hooked by its fast-paced nature and the constant sense of urgency that kept me on the edge of my seat.

The game's mechanics are both simple to grasp and incredibly deep, allowing for a satisfying learning curve that keeps you coming back for more. The variety of characters and their distinct abilities add an extra layer of strategy, making each playthrough a fresh and exciting adventure.

One of the standout features of Vampire Survivors is its dynamic difficulty progression. As you delve deeper into the game, the challenges intensify, providing a constant test of your skills. The sense of accomplishment upon overcoming increasingly difficult levels is immensely rewarding and keeps the adrenaline pumping.

Visually, the pixel art style of Vampire Survivors is charming and nostalgic, reminiscent of classic arcade games. The game's soundtrack complements the intense action perfectly, immersing you in its dark and mysterious world.

What truly sets Vampire Survivors apart is its replayability. Each run feels like a new experience, and the randomized elements keep the gameplay fresh and exciting. The game's community and developer support also contribute to its longevity, with regular updates and new content that ensure there's always something new to discover.

In conclusion, Vampire Survivors is not just a game; it's an exhilarating journey into the heart of challenging gameplay and strategic depth. If you're a fan of roguelike experiences with a vampiric twist, this game is an absolute must-play. Prepare to be blasted into a world of thrilling survival, where every decision counts and victory is all the more sweet.

If you liked Robotron: 2084 for it's primitive graphics, but wished that one joystick was broken so you couldn't control where you were shooting, then Vampire Survivors might be the next best thing.  Don't take it from me, though.  We've got a guest appearance from one of the stars of the game, so without further ado, I present an Interview with the Vampire.

[i]Otter: Thank you for taking the time to be with us today. I'll get things started, since we have a lot of ground to cover.[/i]

Vampire: As long as it's not hallowed ground.  Mwa haha. I kid, but it's great to be here.

[i]O: The player is up against a wide variety of enemies, and in large numbers.  How did you coordinate such a cast?[/i]

V: Well, we really wanted to focus on the diversity in the evil creature community, and celebrate the different ways we have to maul, mutilate, defile, and desecrate the player, so we went all out.  From evil bats, to mummies, zombies and witches, mean trees, very evil bats, cryptic eyes, you name it, we got it.

[i]O: Impressive.  Although I couldn't help but notice they all employ a similar strategy.[/i]

V: There is that, true.  There wasn't time to do much rehearsal, so we just kind of went with "Everyone move directly toward the player at all times".

[i]O: Understandable.  Still, it is a bit unfortunate, since a player with evolved garlic and lightning can just stand there, and the enemies sort of...[/i]

V: They all die.  Yes, we're working on that, and to be sure, there is a way to go, but we do have an eternity to work with, so I'm sure things will improve.

[i]O: Well, I do wish you luck in the future.  Thank you for your time.[/i]

V: Glad to do it, and I would like to say to any players reading this.  Just, take it easy on the garlic, will ya?

I didn't really care for the game for 2 main reasons:
1. graphics. I know this isn't going to be a problem for many, so if you think the graphics are great...great. I don't like 8-bit style much. I had hoped I could look passed it, but I couldn't.

2. lack of player agency in combat. This is the big one and the main reason I quit and got a refund. I cannot control the attacks at all. They're all automatic. I don't want to play a combat game where I only control movement. If I can't control when and how I attack, I have no interest in playing.

If neither of these things bother you...then you'll probably enjoy the game. But they were both deal breakers for me and I got a refund.

Highly Recommended!

This game is even MORE valuable that that box of snack cakes you would have bought with those three dollars.
More maps, more characters, more weapons, more MUSIC.
Hot damn, the music is fantastic, with an all new soundtrack that you can switch up during matches.

Lots of stuff has been added to the base game. No DLC required to access a lot of stuff this game has.

The gameplay gets faster and more difficult the more you progress and after a while, you can make choices to determine how hard the game gets.

There are combinations in this game that you can use to wreck the game itself. It doesn't matter how beefy your pc is, it doesn't matter if you have the CPU Lag Fix enabled. If you know what you're doing, you can become a godslayer and bring the engine to a near halt with the amount of death, destruction, and particle effects you can cause.

Play this.

(ORIGINAL REVIEW)
Will give you more enjoyment than the box of Little Debbie snack cakes you were thinking about buying with that $3.
Currently under Early Access, this game continues to get regular updates, adding new characters, items, and areas with their own fantastic music.
Vampire Survivors may be a cheap game, but it isn't cheap on vision.
It plays like an arcade game in a similar vain to Smash TV, dropping your totally not Castlevania character onto a map with a top-down view, putting a weapon in your hands, and you just start swinging/shooting/blasting.
Direct your 16-bit avatar in the way of one of the many monstrous denizens and gather jewels to level up and become stronger.
It may start slow and difficult, but keep gathering coins for permanent upgrades and new characters and soon you could become a boss yourself.

Just beware Death.

The first three levels alone are genuinely fun and can keep me occupied for hours and I am very happy with the game overall. The levels get more interesting as you beat them, the characters are abundant, and the potential for all the different item combinations is massive. I love the fact that despite many combinations of items can be fatally flawed, you can still have fun. Death isn't really a penalty either, your run ends sure but there isn't any real loss, which I love. If all of that isn't pretty darn cool to you, then check it, it still updates and actually adds fun stuff.
it's quick casual fun, the combos weapon evolution, and variety of characters make it well worth the insanely low cost.

I've watched Asmongold play this and after maybe 20 minutes I thought "Whoa, this looks fun, I gotta check it out"

Well here we are... This Game is insanely fun!

Despite a lot of RNG to the item drops, you can always outline some builds and follow them more or less, in most runs. There's also so many unlocks to discover in the different stages, you wouldn't believe it at first considering they seem to just endlessly loop.

Also, you'll think "just one more run" quite regularly once you get a little deeper into the game.
Endless chaos, mayhem and loot await. Give it a try, that price is a steal!
Easily 12/10 from me.

Edit 110ish hours later: They keep adding new fun stuff, it's awesome! By the time you've unlocked half the available stuff, you become bullet hell!
It even runs very well on the trash PC at work. You really only need any input device hooked up to a potato. Nice!

Edit: another 200+ hours later: Goddamn man! The DLCs (3 at the moment) add a ton of great characters and weapons, a bunch of awesome maps, and the Adventures are pretty fun as well. You'll unlock so many tools to tweak runs as you want them to go, difficulty will more or less be up to your tastes. Gimp yourself in one way or another, boost the enemies, disable items from the RNG pool and make that aspect more bearable. Somehow it never truly gets boring.
The perfect pick up and play game.

The moment I realized this game was just not worth it was when I reached minute 22 out of 30 in a run, had all my gear upgraded, and realized that I had nothing else to do except wait 8 more minutes for the run to end. I waited those 8 more minutes more or less just standing in one area, occasionally moving to collect gems, and doing nothing else. Subsequent runs have had me in the same situation again and again. I get that this is a cheap game made by one guy, but I would not recommend this at any price point. It's a roguelike with no real skill expression, it loses steam once you get a few upgrades, the gameplay is repetitive, and it really struggles to be engaging for the last 30% of each level. In a word: it's boring.

Strongly recommend against purchasing.

It's three dollars. Three, !@#$ing, dollars. I really don't need to say any more, but I guess I will.

Vampire Survivors is a reverse bullet hell (a bullet heaven?) rogue-lite where *YOU* are the bullet hell and a swarm of enemies comes after you. Every run is just walking around to pick up stuff and dodge enemies/aim your weapons at the enemies, and making decisions on items/upgrades. It's very addicting (do NOT start playing if you have anything to do tomorrow/any important project deadlines coming) despite its simplistic gameplay. Make builds, unlock a bunch of stuff, and have fun.

Value-wise, it's THREE DOLLARS, so little to no regrets will be had, plus the amount of content alone for the price is insane. Modern-day AAA games have issues having over 20h in their fully-released game, meanwhile, this $3 EARLY ACCESS game had me playing for 36h to 100% it (as of patch 0.8). Cannot wait for more!

Update: As of the Emergency Meeting update/DLC, buying all the DLC even at full price is still worth. Just buy the damn game already and enjoy it.

Very cool game, at least for the initial 20-30 plays.

However, a couple of related things I really didn't like:
1) One run is too long - I don't want to spoil anything, but it should be half as long.
2) As you get powerful (after some initial set of plays), the amount of effects on the screen becomes unbearable. I have never had any issue whatsoever with any other game, but I can barely get through one play of this, as I feel a slight dizziness after it.

Overall, I'm glad I played it, and at this price, it is totally worth a try. But I'm also probably not going to play it again.

Vampire Survivors had the potential to be an engaging and thrilling experience, but it ultimately left me with a bitter aftertaste due to its lack of diversity and inclusion.

The game revolves around vampires, a concept rich with possibilities for diverse characters and storylines. Unfortunately, the developers missed a golden opportunity to embrace inclusivity. The character choices feel limited and stereotypical, and it's disheartening to see such a one-dimensional representation in a game that could have explored a broader range of identities.

In a gaming industry that is gradually recognizing the importance of diverse narratives, Vampire Survivors feels like a step backward. The repetitive nature of the characters reinforces outdated tropes and fails to resonate with a more varied player base.

With over 70 hours in this game, I have to say it is one of my go-to's when I want something mindless to burn some time. For the price, even if purchasing the full game and all of the DLC, it really is a bargain. While it takes a bit to learn early what is going on, it's worth playing. Once mastered, it's what brings one to be able to make runs with little effort and kick back with it.

It is not that it takes long to play or finish, I've completed each DLC's full content in around 30 minutes or less. It is not that the graphics are great. Although, they are solid and show little to no issues regardless of the system. The music is good though I tend to turn it down or off after a bit because it becomes repetitive. The fact that it's spawned a different genre and many clones is a testament to the Devs and what they've managed to achieve. Added to the point of price and how low the cost is overall, I recommend this game to anyone looking at the genre.

I will say that of all the content that's come out after release, the one thing that I've not enjoyed was the "story mode." I was hoping for some in-depth context of the origins and reasons for the runs. Something akin to say Children of Morta. Maybe I'm just missing it, but a paragraph at the beginning of each run with what is essentially playing through the whole game again is a little bit of a letdown. I do not think this is enough to prevent me from encouraging purchasing and playing, but I was anticipating a little more.

Overall, the game as is, continues to pull me back with the release of each DLC, if only to keep my game completion at 100%.

Note: 
This review is based off base game AND all DLC content.(To date)
[Among-Us DLC is amazing!]

This game is the best game I have ever played. 

The main reason i consider it the best is because of the perfect rate of progression. 
Your not thrown into an intimidating mess of abilities, characters and maps. 
The game slowly introduces you to each mechanic one run at a time. It makes for way more exciting game play. 

It also lets you take charge of what you would like to unlock next with only the spoiler of the item picture to guess what it does or a character silhouette. 

The player is not locked into choosing specific characters and items. They all have benefits making them all super fun to play.

Vampire survivors has an amazing way it approaches maps. When you first play it your under the illusion that its just a simple map but you'd be fooled to think its only that Adventuring through the maps and revealing secrets is another one of the great game designs.

Not to mention.. its split screen which is amazing with friends!

I did have a few negative thoughts on the game but they really did not take away from the experience.

Cons;
A small handful of characters felt kind of bad due to the amount of similarity between others.(3 only)

Secrets codes. While I get the codes are handy a prompt would have been nice to warn that by using the code the player would not be able to do the challenge. 

The latest update adding all the silhouettes of all the characters. This is not good it takes away from the mystery and excitement of the unknown I really hope they change it back.

All in All this is an amazing game and if you haven't bought it your missing out on a not so hidden gem.

Incredibly simple to learn gameplay loop with tons and tons of different characters and weapons to play, which can make thousands of different build styles if you wanna mess around with something new to break up the standard "powerful" builds that you use to always complete a level.

The only downside is that a full run usually takes at least 40 minutes (30 minute timer + 10 minutes to pick your level ups throughout the run), but there is an option that cuts that time in half that you can unlock.

The DLC is also really fun, and for such a cheap game you'll get so much time out of it if you're broke like me and need to get lots of bang for your buck. If you like "survivor-style" reverse bullet hell games, or give them a try, this is literally the game that made that blueprint popular, and for good reason.

In this game, you play as Tristan Brash, a 'Survivor' of the town of Requiem.
Count Duragon, the titular 'Vampire', features prominently in the cover art, as well as the game, appearing at various checkpoint in order to halt your progress through the open world.

Find extra weapons in the caskets strewn through each section of the sprawling locations.
Level up your character by purchasing upgrade points between Chapters.

Graphics, music, sound, and AI, are all well-designed, making you feel as if you're living the adventure.
The voice-acting is second-to-none, and I can't help but wonder how they got permission to use that music video.

As an ardent fan of the Diablo series, I was overjoyed to embark on the dark and treacherous realm of Diablo 4. With nearly 20 hours of immersive gameplay under my belt, I stand here in awe of the epic journey that awaits any intrepid adventurer who dares to traverse its sinister landscapes. Allow me to share my experience, which has undoubtedly left an indelible mark on my gaming soul.

From the moment I stepped foot into Diablo 4, I was greeted by a breathtaking world meticulously crafted by the visionary minds at Blizzard Entertainment. The attention to detail is second to none, with hauntingly beautiful environments that simultaneously evoke a sense of dread and wonder. Every corner of this world pulsates with life, and the atmospheric graphics draw you in, making it impossible to escape its grasp.

The gameplay mechanics of Diablo 4 are nothing short of addictive. The combat is an exhilarating dance of destruction, whether I was unleashing devastating spells or wielding mighty weapons. The fluidity and responsiveness of the controls heightened my sense of empowerment, enabling me to effortlessly dispatch hordes of foes in a symphony of chaos.

But Diablo 4 is not merely about mindless hack-and-slash action. The intricate web of lore and storytelling weaves its magic throughout the game. Engrossing quests and captivating dialogue breathe life into the rich tapestry of Diablo's universe, introducing memorable characters and gripping narrative arcs that kept me invested and hungry for more.

The character progression system in Diablo 4 is a testament to its depth and replayability. As I honed my skills and unlocked new abilities, I felt a genuine sense of growth and evolution. The freedom to customize my character's playstyle and experiment with various builds added an additional layer of excitement, ensuring that no two playthroughs would ever be the same.

It would be remiss of me not to mention the cooperative multiplayer aspect of Diablo 4, which amplifies the experience to staggering heights. Joining forces with fellow adventurers, battling formidable bosses together, and sharing in the spoils of our conquests created a sense of camaraderie that is truly unparalleled.

In terms of longevity, Diablo 4 offers an expansive endgame that guarantees countless hours of enjoyment. From the challenging dungeons and raids to the endless pursuit of powerful loot, the game continually entices you to push your limits and prove your mettle. With future updates and expansions promised by the developers, the Diablo 4 experience promises to be an enduring odyssey.

In conclusion, Diablo 4 is an absolute masterpiece that has captivated my gaming heart. Its awe-inspiring visuals, addictive gameplay, immersive storytelling, and robust multiplayer elements combine to create a gaming experience that is nothing short of legendary. If you seek an adventure that will leave you spellbound and craving for more, Diablo 4 is an absolute must-have. Prepare yourself, brave adventurer, for a journey that will forever be etched in your gaming memories.

When I first watched a friend of mine play this, I have to admit it looked a little lack-luster considering the only gameplay controls are movement and select your upgrades. But after watching a few more runs I began to understand... 

This game has a very large pool of items , characters, maps, gameplay modifiers and secrets to unlock and play with. Like any good roguelike it allows you to mix and match combinations to make each run unique. I was impressed by the amount of content you get for only £7.17 (including DLCs). Every handful of runs I would unlock a new gameplay element that allows me to change the game even more. This game feeds that itch that is scratched by games like Risk of Rain 2 and has that same "just one more run" feeling to it. I have on more than one occasion sat down to play a single run and ended up playing 4 or more...  And even after getting all of the achievements and playing for 60 hours I still feel like I have not seen all the content this game has to offer. I know i haven't unlocked all the characters yet.

TL;DR : 
[list]
[*] basic gameplay
[*] fast, chaotic and fun
[*] lots of content
[*] good price
[*] much replay-ability
[*] fun, non-grindy achievements
[*] great on Steam Deck (might make u lag :) )
[*] VERY addictive
[*] no vampires (yet?)
[/list]
If you enjoy the rogue-like/lite genre you will enjoy this game! 
Highly recommend!

I haven't reviewed this yet? How have I not reviewed this yet?!

Regardless, this is an absolutely fantastic game and very deserving of its Overwhelmingly Positive (currently 98% for both recent and all reviews) rating. Getting through the "base" level of content would probably only take you 7-10 hours, but there is so much hidden away that you can discover and explore. I've not even made it through unlocking all the secrets on the secret menu (despite using guides to do so... yes, I'm that type of gamer lol) and I'm over 50 hours in. The gameplay is extremely satisfying, the aesthetics are dope, and unlocking new characters and secrets is a never-ending drive that I love (and that doesn't feel too frustrating beyond my difficulties finding the damn cheese... don't ask). 

Oh, and did I mention the base game is only $5? And the DLCs are only $2?! (Besides the Among Us DLC, but that is literally... $0.50 more. Oh no, my bank account, it's broken by this MASSIVE cost. /s) Point is, this game is incredibly cheap, considering the huge value you can get out of it. 10/10, would recommend the base game and DLCs (I have not yet tried the Among Us one, but the other two absolutely add a ton of value to this already high-value game).

In a vacuum, I'm indifferent toward this game. It's very much style over substance (though I don't find the visual design to be very appealing) and it lacks the challenge and complexity that makes roguelikes interesting to me. With the added context of the effect this game has had on indie game development though, I abhor it. The amount of titles released in the past year that are essentially visual reskins of this game is ridiculous. The genre of Action Roguelike that was once defined by uniquely fun games like [i]Hades[/i], [i]Dead Cells[/i], and [i]Risk of Rain[/i] is now being flooded with uninspired variations of the same boring ass game. It's a sad waste of talent and market space that I pray fizzles out as soon as possible.

I played Holocure for somewhere around 120-150 hours, obtained 100% of all content available from the most recent update (which added Korone, and others) and then randomly decided to give this game a go, since it was an inspiration for Holocure.

The first complaint I have is that there is no aiming in this game. Your directional attacks are based on your characters current direction and you cannot strafe or fire in a direction you are not facing.

[strike]The second complaint that I have is that without mods (more on this later) there are many limitations that make very little sense, such as being limited to one Golden Egg per stage, which means you will have to quit the stage after obtaining the 1 from the shop and the 4 from killing a few specific superbosses from the end game that spawn when you collect a certain item (one item for each boss) which means grinding stats takes [b]ages[/b] to increase your permanent stats of your favorite characters, even if you have huge stacks of coins laying around after buying everything you can (though I'm not quite there yet, but I've had 50k plus and found it annoying that I have to run 5 stages to buy 5 golden eggs, so I can definitely understand the pain of someone who has a million or more sitting in their coffers being forced to run one stage for one golden egg when they can afford hundreds of them)[/strike] EDIT: This has been changed! No longer an issue!

And my last complaint is related to the secrets in the game. Not a 'real' complaint, just me whining about how much I have struggled in figuring things out because I'm too stubborn to go online for a guide.

All that in mind... This game is $5. Watch the trailer and see if it looks like something you hate. If it looks like you won't hate it then stop thinking and buy it. 

Satisfying progression, interesting mechanics, hilarious secrets, and a killer soundtrack that apparently no one else is talking about. This game is worth $20, but you'll pay at most a fraction of that, so just buy it.

And if you're as stingy as me with your wallet... then go play Holocure for a few minutes to get a feel for the gameplay there, and then come back to play the superior game of that style... at least until the next round of Hololive characters are added.

If you couldn't tell from the previous bit, I got this game as a means of killing time to wait until the next update for the unmoddable Holocure... and I ended up liking this game a helluva lot more. I would really appreciate a strafe feature, but besides that... Vampire Survivors is the superior game in almost every possible way. Though I will say that Holocure will still have my heart because Korone is best doggo... unless someone makes a Korone mod for Vampire Survivors. [i]Nudge, nudge, wink wink.[/i]

You won’t understand Vampire Survivors until it happens to you. 

‘It’ is particularly hard to define. It’s the point where all your weapons and items blend seamlessly into a rainbow of death. It’s the moment you watch every enemy enjoy a lifespan of half a second, before they’re wiped off the face off the earth by a torrent of special effects. Yet as much as I could continue to list examples, none of these will actually be able to capture the sheer [i]euphoria[/i] of the thing – of beating the numbers game, of literally sitting back and enjoying the carnage, of…

Well, perhaps we’re getting ahead of ourselves. Firstly, it’s worth taking a step back to digest what Vampire Survivors is actually all about. As it turns out, however, only a brief step is needed; you pick a static character sprite - each with their own unique weapon - and move around the screen to both dodge foes and destroy them with said weapon. Kill enough, and you level up, allowing you to add new gear to your arsenal or power up your existing stuff. That’s it. That’s the entire thing. This is game design stripped down to the barest essentials – your movement keys, and an occasional tap of the space-bar to confirm a menu of two. That's everything you need.

[h1]Embrace the chaos[/h1]

Yet, as classics of design such as Pac-man and Tetris will tell you, you don’t need anything intricate to create a compelling experience. The joy in Vampire Survivors is mastering those key gameplay elements. It’s all about deftly weaving your way through the small gaps left in the frankly ludicrous amount of enemies to grab those precious experience points in the brief moments you can. Then it’s about learning what each weapon and skill does, and – crucially – how they synergise with each other. Simple throwing knives not enough? Pair them up with the bracer, and watch those singular knives become an endless torrent that would leave even the most powerful machine gun jealous. 

This builds and builds, until you reach that point of ‘it’ – where it all clicks together, and it just feels so good. Your attacks can end up swarming the screen, and it’s entirely feasible to create runs that require no input from you that still end in victory. I’ve seen the tagline “Be the bullet hell” be used by the developers, and I think that’s very apt to explain what’s going on here; this is a game leaning into the idea of glorious excess so hard the concept practically starts to strain against itself. Even the sheer act of opening an item chest is overblown; hitting a jackpot on these starts with a shower of fireworks, ramps the music up to 11, and then sees more rewards swing in from the side of the screen as your reward plays out. It’s like the developers have tapped directly into the pleasure centres of the brain, and are determined to feed it with as much serotonin as possible. 

This extends beyond what occurs in as singular run of a level, as well. Each success sees you unlock more and more features. There are extra weapons, which naturally add variety (and insanity) to your play. There are extra levels and gameplay modes, which modify things in ways such as speeding things up or just making the entire experience infinitely harder. And there’s such a vast amount of them, as well; after over 15 hours I’ve only just opened up what essentially feels like a campaign mode, which is so in-depth it has its own section dedicated to it on the menu screen.

[h1]Lost in translation[/h1]

One of my complaints, however, is that the sheer amount of content in the game isn’t that well reflected and presented through said menus. Beyond a brief explanation when you first unlock a new feature, there’s little guidance on what everything does, which can be overwhelming, and not in a good way. Some descriptions or explanations when highlighting stuff, or even general tool tips, wouldn’t go too far amiss. If anything, they feel like a strange omission.  

My other complaint is that, despite all attempts and intentions to spice things up, the core gameplay does essentially boil down to doing the same thing over and over again. Survive the initial onslaught, become a nigh-on indestructible demon, rinse and repeat.  Realistically I accept this isn’t really a slight against the game’s minimalist design, which honestly is one of its greatest strengths. It’s perhaps more a recognition that this isn’t the sort of title where you’re going to want to settle yourself down and play it for hours on end. It’s definitely best played in short bursts, when the need for an endorphin hit strikes you. The words ‘Steam Deck’ come to mind – as does the word ‘Switch’, come to think of it, but I’m not sure if that’s a dirty word to say around here. 

Still, these are trifling concerns in the grand scheme of things. Vampire Survivors is offering so much at a price that is so very little – at the time of writing, what amounts to essentially a generic brand cup of coffee. To split hairs over some minor concerns seems necessary and, indeed, perhaps missing the entire point as to what is on offer here. You should get this and really find out what ‘it’ is for yourself. You won’t regret it. 
(Oh, and I’ve still not survived any actual vampires, mind you. Not sure what’s up with that.)

Vampire Survivors, minimalist rogue-lite tarzı ile son zamanlarda oldukça popüler hale gelen bir hayatta kalma oyunu. Şimdi size oyunu detaylı bir şekilde anlatıp inceleyelim:

Oyunun Amacı:

    Cehennem ateşinde hayatta kalma mücadelesi veriyorsunuz.
    Binlerce vampir, hayalet ve diğer yaratığı avlayarak şafağa kadar dayanmanız gerekiyor.
    Her gece hayatta kalarak altın biriktirip, bir sonraki denemede yeni beceriler, silahlar ve karakterler açarak kendinizi güçlendiriyorsunuz.

Oynanış Mekaniği:

    Oyun oldukça basit bir oynanışa sahip. Hareketinizi kontrol ediyorsunuz, silahlarınız ise otomatik olarak ateş ediyor.
    Yönünü değiştirerek ve stratejik hareketler yaparak gelen düşman dalgalarından kaçıyor ve onları avlıyorsunuz.
    Silah seçimi ve güçlendirmeler çok önemli. Doğru kombinasyonları seçerek hayatta kalma şansınızı yükseltiyorsunuz.
    Her gece harita değişiyor, size yeni stratejiler deneme imkanı veriyor.

Oyunun Olumlu Yönleri:

    Basit ama bağımlılık yapan oynanış: Kolay öğrenilen ancak ustalaşması zor bir oynanış sunuyor.
    Rogue-lite unsurları: Her denemede farklı bir deneyim yaşamanızı sağlıyor, tekrar oynanabilirliği yüksek.
    Yüksek hızlı aksiyon: Sürekli hareket halinde olmanız gereken tempolu bir oynanışa sahip.
    Minimalist grafikler ve müzik: Eski klasik arcade oyunlarını hatırlatan bir tarzı var, nostaljik hissettiriyor.
    Uygun fiyat: Oyun oldukça uygun bir fiyata sahip, fiyat/performans açısından başarılı.

Oyunun Olumsuz Yönleri:

    Basitlik zamanla tekrarlayıcı hale gelebilir: Uzun süreli oynanışlarda aynı aksiyonun devam etmesi bazı oyuncuları sıkabilir.
    Hikaye ve karakter eksikliği: Oyun hikaye veya karakter gelişimi sunmuyor, sadece hayatta kalmaya odaklanıyor.
    Optimizasyon sorunları: Bazı platformlarda performans sorunları yaşanabiliyor.

Sonuç Olarak:

Vampire Survivors, oynanışı kolay ancak ustalaşması zor, bağımlılık yapan bir hayatta kalma oyunu. Basit grafikleri ve yüksek hızlı aksiyonu ile sizi cehennemin derinliklerine sürüklüyor. Oyunun rogue-lite unsurları sayesinde her denemede farklı bir deneyim yaşamanızı sağlıyor.  Eğer basit ama eğlenceli bir oyun arıyorsanız, Vampire Survivors tam size göre. Ancak derin hikaye veya karakter gelişimi beklemiyorsanız hayal kırıklığı yaşayabilirsiniz.

Puansal Değerlendirme:

Oynanış: 9/10
Görseller: 7/10
Müzik: 8/10
Tekrar Oynanabilirlik: 8/10
Genel Puan: 8/10
