An addictive game more than a well designed one. It can eat up hours of your time without you realising, but it doesn't respect that it's your time. Once you hit a stride the game can't keep up with you and doesn't accelerate itself to try.

(tl;dr BUY THIS GAME) When I bought this game, I thought it might be a fun time killer, spend an hour or two on it a day after classes or whatever, play it while watching a stream or something. I did NOT expect to get so addicted to the game that I'd spend nearly 24 hours on it in the first 4 days of me purchasing it. Like this is probably a very polarizing game i'll be honest, you likely love it or hate it with no in-between, but just hear me out: Go watch AliensRock or someone on youtube play a few runs of this game, and if you think for even a moment "hey this seems fun", BUY IT. Even if it's not for you, you've helped some cool devs out. Hell, buy it just for the soundtrack (which bangs). Steam remote play is kinda janky but works like a dream with this game, and playing this with my friend for the first time tonight was great. There's progression, there's unlocks tied to Steam achievements, there's an adventure mode with a sort of plot? Among Us DLC in like 2 days??? Speaking of silly content, this game wears clear inspiration on its sleeve with many silly little tongue-in-cheek jokes hidden all over the place (the music for the church level quotes Bach's Toccata and Fugue and when I heard it for the first time I had to pause to laugh for like 5 minutes bc it was just in-and-out before going back to being its own thing). Oops this got long in the tooth, i just really enjoyed this game it's WILD how it's captivated me. This game is like if someone made a super drug for people with ADHD

The game is quite entertaining and addicting due to its simple control scheme and gameplay. You would think you get bored after just being able to move your character and it attacking by itself, but the progression, level variation and enemies keep it interesting for  probably way too long to be healthy. For the Price, even with future DLC, I say the game is an outstanding instant buy.

I started playing the game in my phone out of curiosity and dang I was hooked up. I only stopped because it was destroying my neck and eyes to play on a small screen so I had to get it here.

Despite being super simple when it comes to gameplay (You just walked around, auto-shoots, and choose upgrades), it's super gratifying and fun and the amount of content and unlocks will keep you entertained for a long time.

It's funny because it feels like it has like all the marks of a game that could have been incredibly predatory and full of microtransactions but they made all these addictive features, design and choices and then just made it a super cheap game with no bullshit. It's perfect.

It's the best game to get a dopamine injection right into your brain, either for a quick session or for a couple of hours because the game is also one of those that make you go "Just one more round". Music is banger, graphics are charming, and it's full of little things that give it depth and fun. Specially considering the price it's hard to not recommend it and it's gonna appeal to casual gamers to a more "hardcore" audience if you want. The amount of positive reviews are well deserved.

I have to admit that this one put me off a bit at first. I mean, that cheesy art on the thumbnail coupled with assets that are clearly very “inspired” by [i]Castlevania[/i] games doesn’t exactly scream “Game of the Year” to me.

But that’s exactly what you have here. There’s a reason it was nominated for a bunch of awards when it was released in 2022. I still kind of wonder if that “reason” is some kind of charm spell hidden in the game’s files…

I don’t mean that in any derogatory way, of course. I’ve played this game for hours and loved every second of it. (It was the first game I sank any meaningful amount off time into on my Steam Deck, for god’s sake.) It’s just that this is, on its face, a very simple game. Most of the player input, outside of menu navigation, is moving your character. Attacking and spell casting are both done automatically – the player only needs to position the character among the throngs of enemies for optimal obliteration. To me, when the enemies are coming at you in full force, it ends up feeling like I’m navigating a moving maze as I try squeezing through gaps in the enemy front. That is, until you get swallowed by the mob or Death himself comes for you and the level ends.

And that’s kind of it. Don’t be fooled, though – the gameplay loop is addictive as fuck. There’s something about watching your leveled-up spells ripping through a hundred skeletons at a time that never gets old. Besides that, trying different characters and loadouts to see what is most effective kept me busy for a long time.

If you’re looking for something entertaining to kill some time, you’d be hard pressed to find something better than this one. But, if you’re looking for something to really sink your teeth into, you might want to look elsewhere. Still, at this price, it’s probably worth picking up anyway.

First of all, let me say that this game's original soundtrack is one of the best I've heard in years, since maybe NieR Automata.

I was initially hesitant on buying it on Steam, but then I eventually read an article somewhere saying the game was also free on Android which I then tried it out during an international flight. 

It ended up being one of those games where you have to play it to really understand the appeal, since the trailers alone hardly looked convincing. I really had blast though, enough that I decided to buy it on Steam anyway for the couple of dollars it was worth. 

For a game where the only means of playing is by moving around and choosing your upgrades, it's is wildly addicting. 

My only complaint is how easy the game gets. The game eventually becomes so easy that you have to plan out what handicaps you want to find yourself a challenge. From that, it would be nice if there was an in-game "Challenge" list to do specific scenarios with limitations.

Edit: I finished the game, then I bought the DLC for two bucks. And I never usually buy DLCs. It's that good of a game.

[b]A trifecta of perfection; simplicity meets complexity meets enormity.[/b]

The proverbial rabbit hole into a budding genre, "reverse bullet horde action roguelike survivor" that was the first to hook me (and the best). 

Vampire Survivors hits a spot. With that sit down and play simplicity, it's not difficult to grasp what needs to be done in the early stages. Survive...

...And it feels good to mow down a revolving carousel of enemies of all shapes, sizes and colors. In fact, seeing what horrors lie beyond the next 5 minute mark is all part of the appeal. 

Then there's the choices, they come in that perfect steady stream. Bit by bit, your pitiful projectiles give way to whole new beast of destruction pixel pizzazz. Spinning axes, whizzing cats, explosions, magic, and powers beyond (at least my) imagination. It all adds up to some kind of coherency in your mind and total chaos on the screen. Unless you look for the patters beneath. 

That's what has got me so impressed with this genre. Drawing from tried and true mechanics, hearkening to schmups, bullet hell, deckbuilder, ARPG, and who-know-what's-next, these games are all trying to pack that right blend of variables. And we're getting picky. If the progression doesn't feel right or the movement is off...it's only a matter of time before it shows. 

Vampire Survivors is a labor and love and these variables have all been tweaked to near perfection whilst still allowing plenty of room for evolution (see DLC, but additionally see collab with Among Us!). This game is certainly not going anywhere and I have no doubt will continue to offer a lot.

The achievements, secrets, challenges, and just straight up experimenting or pushing your PC's framerate to the limits is a powerful continuum of reasons that this game and others will no doubt continue to evolve.

The characters, weapons, vocabulary, levels, and the ever endearing treasure box techno party will always hold a special place in my gaming heart. I'll be looking at many other games in the genre going forward, with some notable releases for sure. 

Perhaps not the textbook 'original' or not even 'the best', Vampire Survivors is a phenomena, a great game and testament to a developers creativity. People love playing games that just hit that spot!

Vampire Survivors started as an experiment: could the techniques used to make slot machines addictive still work without the predatory monetization scheme inherent to gambling? To say it succeeded is an understatement. Calling it the most important game of the decade is probably premature, but that hasn't stopped people from doing so. Buy it. Buy all the DLC, Kill gacha dead.
fun

Alright after 100%ing the entire game, the DLC, and the secrets I can finally leave my review.

I bought this game and all of its DLC for like 9 bucks when I was sick and have almost no lifed this game since. I absolutely adore bullet hells and the way this game spins that formula on its head in a new and interesting way was exactly what the genre needed. The thing that also separates this game from other bullet hells and especially Vampire Survivors clones is just the amount of content. Even on the surface this game has so much to do, but somehow there's EVEN MORE to do under the surface. The end game has end game content, the bosses have bosses, the DLC has DLC, and the music goes so fucking hard. Just how many times the devs seemed to say to themselves, "fuck it, let's add more because we can" absolutely astonishes me and is the reason I love this game and it's one of my favorite games literally ever. As someone who loves achievements, I also adore the fact that game progression is tied directly to the achievements so 100%ing the game isn't tedious and is as simple as just beating the game and unlocking everything. It makes the dopamine in my brain very happy and probably the other main reason this is one of my favorite games ever. I wish more games would do this. 

Much recommend if you want to play casually, or no life the game for 65+ hours like I did. The one thing I will say though, is that I NEED that Among Us DLC right NOW because now that I've done literally everything there is to do, I don't really know what to do in the game anymore and probably won't open it for a while.  Now does that matter after the amount of time I put into the game already? I'll let you decide for yourself.

Either way I very much enjoyed my time with this game, and for such a low price there's literally no reason to not at least pick the base game up. Support the devs, they deserve it.

Also, I see that Street Fighter II Turbo reference. I see you Vampire Survivors.

Catastrophically overrated. I might've found it fun a decade and a half ago. I've played a lot of survivors but this is, bar none, the most boring. Everything but movement is automated, so if you like those auto-clicker games this might be a nice time sink for you. Even then, movement itself is utterly pointless outside of artificially grafted mechanics such as the coveted vacuum pickup which sucks in all experience gems on the floor, of which there are ALOT; you can't do much in the way of collecting them all because of the nature of the automated attack system. There are also sometimes swarms which occasionally blitz across the screen (forcing you to dodge), which were fun, but as far as I can remember this only happened on the first map.
For a large majority of the level, you could stand completely fixed in one position, never moving, and you would succeed all the same (assuming you passively gained exp).

The graphics are vapid - if not painful to look at, making me feel forced against my own will when I'm told by luminous green arrows to run in one direction across the undifferentiated, bland landscape for some unlockable or additional powerup (and miss all the experience gems in the process; infuriating!)

I think a huge step in terms of making this game more enjoyable would be to reduce the prevalence of the all-encompassing automated gameplay loop. For example, they could give you an option to toggle specific skills at the demand of an assigned hotkey (this way you have an opportunity to reduce the spread of gems and at the same time inject player autonomy into the currently very, very boring equation). Add enemies that do something interesting other than run straight towards you, such as enraging them if you hit them during a visible animation-cue.

At the end of the 30 minute gameplay loop, instead of a thrilling final showdown with some unearthly demon to practise the culmination of your exponential power creep, you are immediately insta killed by an immortal phantom?? I don't understand this. There needs to be some reason for the 30 minutes I just invested into the game. Why is there no boss at the end of the stage?

Honestly, this game throws you so many curveballs for unlocking content at every turn, and does it so masterfully that it doesn't make you wonder "How did they ever find this out!?" It has that old-school style of obscure methods of unlocking certain items and content, but gives the player tools to allow them to find said content without a wiki. There's hidden characters, evolved weapons, alternate character skins, new mechanics, and more stuff to find in the game. Every character has unique buffs they gain as they level up, and the game incentivises replaying levels to complete them with most of the roster. It tells you just enough to keep you playing, and keeps the rest hidden for you to discover

The Art n graphics - this game has graphics just like the good old days and a art style that will never leave your heart! the art is good and i truly enjoy it!

The music - has truly good music! its not straight rock and roll or metal or Mic Gordon but the music speaks to you and  i enjoy it. 

The Game play - slightly repetitive but you wont mind as you unlock more and more stuff! FEED ME MORE!!!

Tons of secrets and i mean tons of em! they even have a cheat code system in the game which i love!... and only used a little... lol. only real problem with the game is NO ONLINE CO-OP! when it gets that ill give it a 5 out of 5.

In the end - in the end i give it a 4 out of 5. however i would give this game get a 5 out of 5  if it ever gets ONLINE CO-OP which i would be willing to spend 5 dollars more if it came as a add on or whatever. to play this with friends or family in another state would be awesome! 

this game is good all the way through and its easily a 30 dollar game but its under 20! now thats a a deal! this game deserves far more appreciation than it gets! it truly never bites :)

SO INSTEAD OF DEALING WITH PERPETUAL DREAD, I PLAYED THIS GAME FOR A WEEK STRAIGHT EVERY MOMENT INSTEAD OF LETTING MYSELF HAVE A SINGLE BRAIN CELL DEVOTED TO ANYTHING THAT WAS NOT "GARLIC" AND "FLASHING PIXELS". 

10/10 would use a coping mechanism to avoid crying on a floor in a helpless ball like a toddler who had lost their shoes or becoming 3 possums in a trenchcoat screaming due to life events you cannot control, change or in anyway help but must sit in your suffering helpless, A+ dopamine simulator. 

(the above is not doctor recommended, probably, i'm not a doctor, but i have successfully contained the possum screaming urge to get on with my life as required around this, so do with that what you will).

This game is a must have: takes close to no space, runs on everything, it has nostalgia value, destroying everyone in sight is satisfying like recently laid asphalt and poses a challenge without requiring you to play continuously or to repeat exactly the same moves.

The concept is elegantly simple: it is a reverse bullet hell, in which you have to grow your regularly firing arsenal while enemies will try to attack you.

Bonus for Italians: the game is made by a fellow citizen who moved to London, the names of the characters are obvious in-jokes and some of the music is suggestive of traditional music.

Just buy it, like apparently anyone else, leave it on your machine and use it even just for breaks, it is the best!

[h1]HAVE YOUR ICE CREAM CAKE AND EAT IT TOO! (bUT... IT MIGHT MELT BEFORE YOU FINISH) + FALSE ADVERTISING??[/h1]
While I enjoyed my time with this game, I'm not going to simply gush over it like everyone else. Definitely buy it on sale, but it's far from perfect. 
I thought I was going to have mostly positive things to say about this, but at the near 100% mark I'm just sick of it and feel that it's overstayed its welcome.
Random weapon selection adds nothing to this game except tedium and frustration. With the random selection gone, you could also do away with the irritating-as-hell re-rolls, banishes, seals, etc., fucking etc. All this does is keep you doing mindless (and endless) pre-flight inspections, when all you really want to do is be up in the air flying.
It's like being handed a delicious slice of ice cream cake, and then having to eat it with a fucking demitasse spoon. Before long, the ice cream begins to melt, and the enjoyment you would have is lost because of pointless frustration. You could have simply got a bigger spoon, and enjoyed the cake before it melted, just like you could simply choose your load out each time and enjoy the game before your interest wanes.
This isn't entirely Vampire Saviour fault... I'm just sick of random shit. How much better would Spelunky 2 be in you could simply CHOOSE the jet pack and plasma gun at the start? If I want to put myself through hell and beat the game with one bomb and a toothpick, THAT SHOULD BE MY FUCKING CHOICE, NOT LEFT UP TO SOME RANDOM FCKING B*LLSH*T ALGORITHM. 
I know the reasoning -"Well everyone else is doing it!" We all know that's a stupid reason to do anything, but the gaming industry seems hell bent content on all swinging on the same vine. Until it breaks. (Case in point - look how many fucking clones there are of this game already).
Random selection doesn't promote varied weapon and item selection. Well thought out weapon challenges and unlockables that come from clever item utilisation and experimentation handle that already, so in this regard, random selection becomes a moot point. I fail to see how randomization manages to add a single entertaining aspect to this game, or any game in general for that matter (feel free to present your take / viewpoints on this in the comments and prove me wrong). I'm not a fan of restricting choices, especially with a product I payed for. You can blame growing up with Game Genie for that, because it gave me freedom and opened my eyes to a world of possibilities. This random shit feels like the Anti-Game Genie, and we all know the Anti-version of anything is bad (Anti-Monitor, Anti-Christ, ((Aunti-Edna, when she pinches your checks...?)).
While the game does make you feel great mowing down tons of enemies, it can also be equal parts of tedious and flat out boring as well. There's nothing like getting twenty minutes into a level, not taking a single hit, and then having the screen FILL with enemies in seconds... and you're dead. Fucking piss off. 
As much as I felt great mowing down enemies and discovering secrets, I also had times where I literally fell asleep because there was nothing to do except wait for the level to end.
Many times you can't even see the items on the ground, or any of your character except the life bar, which is always present, except when it goes black it's nearly impossible to see.
The game can also be played one handed while eating a sandwich. The lack of complexity in the controls could be a good or bad thing depending on your point of view, but it could also be part of the reason I fell asleep a few times - I prefer more engaging control schemes. To be fair, this is simplistic to the point of being ridiculous. It was clearly made for touch screens from the start.
There's also not a single vampire in the game. There are vampire bats, and lots of references to Castlevania and other video games (Sonic?), but I call that false advertising ( <- this is a joke. If I get one single comment taking this seriously, I'll be upset). In my mind, the only way to justify it is since it's called Vampire Survivors, these are all characters that survived Dracula's castle, and are now trying to escape through hordes of enemies (as you can see, the game gives you a lot of time to come up with stupid shit like this).
At the end of the day, I got my $2.50ish cdn out of it. I've spent money on far stupider things that I got way less enjoyment from.

This is a really fun game for the price! The visual style is super retro but the gameplay is really fun. If you like Risk of Rain (fyi I've only played 2, can't attest to 1) then you'll definitely like this one. It has the same concept of giant waves of enemies getting increasingly frequent and increasingly powerful at the same time as your character getting increasingly broken. If you don't keep up with the enemy progression, you die, but if you do, boy is it satisfying watching your screen fill up with enemies only to have them die a few frames later.

This is a really great game and I love it to death and will continue to keep up with finishing every achievement as more and more dlc rolls around. The art, style, gameplay, mechanics, and characters are all awesome and exciting to play and always leaves me wanting to explore the game more (when I was starting out). The different maps, enemies, and secrets about the game also kept it super exciting.
I do have a little bit of an issue about the game and that is golden eggs! I'm not a fan of golden eggs whatsoever, it just leads to gamebreaking characters/builds that lessens the challenge of the game or gets rid of the challenge completely because, depending on the amounts of golden eggs, I am completely invincible and one shotting everything. I know that I can turn off the option, it just gives me less of an incentive to turn it off since it is an option and makes getting the achievements easier. I would rather it not be in the game at all honestly, I just recently came back to get the achievements with a character that has 100,000's of golden eggs just because it was easy to get the achievements.

I highly recommend this game to literally anyone but I do HEAVILY suggest you do not go near golden eggs if you want to experience the game in all of its glory of difficulty.

Vampire Survivors is a twin stick shooter that removes the right stick and replaces it with the aesthetic gratification of a slot machine. There is a lot of variation to each run, but it is so minute that it has no appreciable impact on the play experience. This is not a game with a lot of depth or nuance. The gameplay is very intense, but generally more addicting than fun - a great snack, but not a meal. That said, the low-effort, high-reward structure is very compelling and well worth the $4 asking price.

More Depth for those that aren't "tl;dr" by default in life.

One very important detail I need to make clear about myself...
I NEVER PLAY GAMES LIKE THIS. EVER. I have an appreciation for the retro art style in games. But you see, I'm a grown-ass gamer, old by most kid standards today. I grew up as a little kid with the Atari 2600 (from my older siblings) and an original NES. Lots of good memories. Yet I will never forget the wishing and waiting for the days when graphics truly advanced. Even as a teen in the 90's I knew the "3d graphics" of that early era were weak. 

So at this point in life I have no taste to recapture my youth in gaming. I played a lifetime of sidescroll and sprite graphics. I've even had enough low res polygons to fill a second childhood. I DO NOT seek out old style games. I was even dismissive when I first saw VS pop up in my Steam queue, even more as it became a streaming sensation (for however long this lasts.)

Then I finally watched some, a few dudes from Neebs Gaming playing co-op (couch co-op only, no online). I really don't know why but his nudged me to checked it out. -Didn't pick up on the couch co-op only until after purchase.- Despite being disappointed that there is no online co-op (at this time?) I went with it anyway. Now I've spent way way too much time playing games alone, like any normal gamer. So at this point in life I try to avoid single-player stuff and aim for co-op potential. Which lead me to believe I'd get momentary fun out of it. Like 15 minutes. ... I was WRONG.

It IS addictive! Let me explain with my many years and console generations worth of gaming. On the surface it almost seems dumb. You don't even have a fire/attack button! You ONLY move. Everything auto-fires/deploys. The ONLY real effect you have on your loadout/weapons is what you pick when you level up! Early levels will be options for other weapons to use at the same time, or defensive things, or more subtle things like cooldown time, or duration. The MAGIC of the game comes from your choice of combos. Some of which work in conjunction to make very powerful weapons when fully upgraded. At first it feels kind of random. Yet over time there are strategies of combos. You just keep going with it. 

As far as any kind of mobile game, auto-clicker, dopamine trigger games with rewarding sounds, colors, and flashing whatnot is also NOTHING I have any taste for. But this game also feeds you full of it and: I LOVE IT in this game. Those gems start rolling in by the hundreds and it's a constant jingling of points.Level ups feel rewarding. Even the health pick-ups and strike noises all are arcade perfect. The treasure chests also feel really good. The final evolved form of weapons if very rewarding. 

This game has taken SO many little features from old and new genres to create this sense of perfectly distilled classic gaming. It's like a strange modern version of what you imagine all your nostalgic memories of gaming as a kid were like! (weather it be actually lived or inherited nostalgia from the gaming life) This really has taken something so simple and purified even more into basically a free-base version of oldschool gaming. Straight to the brain. The hardest part is getting my right hand to let go of the mouse since there's no use.

Oh even the music Kicks the Hell out of All the Ass! All chiptune yet so amazingly perfect for this. I always turn down the music in games... this one I forgot and I am glad! 

It's also a great palette cleanser. You don't need hundreds of constant hours. Lots of rounds may only be a few minutes. 15 minutes is a good run. 30 minutes completes the level I think? But by then, if you make it to the last few minutes, you'll be in such a gaming zen state that it's a whole other thing!

I first got this game over a year ago and quickly lost interest after just a few in-game hours. I decided to start it up again recently but this time on the steam deck. I must say the game itself for the $5 price tag is worth it but for the deck is a must have. There’s plenty of hours of replay-ability especially for achievement hunters. For the new player, it starts off “slow” and you’ll die fast and often, but as you begin to unlock the “unlocks” and learn how to evolve weapons the game really starts to take off and get you hooked.
i think it has the ability to define a new genre of games. like metroid or bullet hell did in their respective times.

[h1] Vampire Surviors [/h1]

I [b]ADORE[/b] this game in a very weird & unique way. But I still have a lot of gripes, of course.

I have to mention that one of my most hated genres is the rogue-like/lite genre.
And while this is a rogue-lite game, it's one that actually decides to strike out & do something unique with its genre. Creating a spin that's so vast that it created a whole new genre within the rogue genre. Very impressive! I congratulate the developers very honestly.
It's also why I appreciate games like [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/mossfan1/recommended/1313140] Cult of the Lamb [/url] so much, as they're rogue games that actually decide to do something different & noteworthy with their genres instead of following the formulaic tendency the vast majority of other rogue games follow. [i]ugh.[/i]

But just like [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/mossfan1/recommended/1313140] Cult of the Lamb[/url], I'm not sure if I'll ever actually want to get around to beating them.
They're neat games that I've obviously decided to spend quite a few notable hours on, but they're still honor-bound rogue games -- of which is enough to off-set me from finishing them due to solely that. The only rogue game that I've ever come to enjoy enough to actually beating it would be Hellboy: Web of Wyrd.



[h1] Progression Pondering [/h1]

Anyways, moving on from my nonchalant Hellboy: Web of Wyrd shoutout I want to comment on this game's progression.
I don't enjoy it. Kinda.
I'd so much rather prefer the game stuck to simply reaching a certain kill count or reaching a certain time alive within a level to unlock the next one. Because some of these are so darn niche & specific that they crave me to research how to even beat them, because they're on the verge of feeling like discovering some niche easter egg or something more than actual necessary progression. I do not enjoy that.
I wish I could dissect my brain's thought vastly more to translate my raging thoughts into words... but 'nay, just WOW. WOW... I can't even verbalize my frustrations. It's really that outlandish? What the hell were they thinking?
Especially since so much of it is purely luck based or grind based. Not fun.



[h1] The Anti-'Bullet Hell' Game [/h1]

I've heard this game described as an anti-'bullet hell' kind of game, where you create the bullets instead of dodging them. And I cannot agree more!
The combat is great & it becomes greatly enthralling late-game when you've got most of your power-ups from the run maxed out & trying to survive these ever-lasting hordes of enemies, as you desperately try to slither through wherever there should open a new hole from recently killed enemies. Absolutely lovely.
It keeps you constantly on your toes & quite engaged.
It can be a tad sluggish during the start of the round where you don't have a lot of attacks & there are only very few enemies. But it luckily doesn't take too long to get truly started.

A lot of the unlocks per run & permanent ones are very creative & often very fun to play around with.
I appreciate the creativity that has went into this, even if it goes a little overboard at times like the level progression.



[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Listen, I have a lot of shit to say about this game. Negative & positive kinds of shit; both the kind of shit that sprays everywhere but also the kind that just keeps hitting your g-spot as you push it out. Yeah.

Still, I do mostly have fun while playing this game on a moment-to-moment basis. So I feel comfortable recommending this game, regardless of my harsh complaints.

Okay I bought this game on sale for $4 and I've got to say, it was worth my money. I've been playing this on a non-gaming laptop as well as on the Steam Deck. It works just fine on the Steam Deck, without toying around with it too hard (I just choose the standard boot option, from a choice of 3 available when you launch the game).

This game only *looks* like a twin-stick shooter. In fact, you don't actively do any of the shooting. This game is all about unlockables and challenges. You start with a base set of characters that each have a weapon type. The weapons in this game are automatically deployed based on whatever rules the weapon follows (for example, a basic whip will arc around in front of you, similar to Capcom's Strider arcade game; or some "holy water" will fall from above every X amount of time, create a circle of fire on the floor with Y radius and last for N amount of time on the floor). You can learn each character that you have available, learn their base weapons, and then as you upgrade those, you unlock the ability to acquire those for other characters as well. 

You accumulate new characters and their base weapons for use in future runs and that's what keeps this game going.

So this game resembles a twin-stick shooter in appearance, in that you are on a map which is basically an infinitely-scrollable arena and face monsters along the way that come at you in waves in a way. As you kill, you can collect dropped XP which you use to level up. There's also a currency system for unlocking permanent stat buffs in the main menu, as well as being able to use that cash on a merchant for temporary items during future runs (merchant must be unlocked, as does most of the features of this game).

The game opens up a lot over time, going from only a couple of main menu options to unlocking new maps, new modes, a secrets menu, a bestiary, and more. The base-length for a standard run can top out at about 30 minutes, at which point the game generally forces you to die. There are alternate modes you can unlock (like hyper, endless, and more) which switch this up for your liking as well.

There's one "secret" objective in the game that basically caused my laptop to struggle (only onboard intel graphics, on an I7 11xxx series processor with 32gb RAM and an nvme SSD), otherwise the game has run just fine on my laptop. The secret involved essentially leaving the map in a trippy "out of reality" kind of teleport which then places you temporarily on a different map, and that entire sequence was too intense for a non-gaming device based on the visuals of that entire sequence. I made it through after a few minutes of extremely choppy gameplay, where then once the map reverted back, my performance went back to normal. 

I've mostly played using the Xbox 360 wired gamepad for Windows as well. You spend most of the time just using your left analog stick (or moving with the keyboard), while the game otherwise plays itself according to whatever rules are in motion (based on buffs, unlocks, debuffs, etc.).

For the price I paid ($4), it's a fun *almost* auto-play game, and being loaded with objectives and achievements is the incentive to keep going, aside from any personal goals you give yourself (like trying to beat a level without upgrades, or with only 1 weapon, etc.).

I'd recommend checking out some gameplay videos if you're on the fence, otherwise if you appreciate twin stick-style arena shooters, you will likely enjoy this as well!

Vampire Killer Martini
TOTAL TIME: Prep: 5 min
YIELD: 8 servings

Ingredients:
    1 serrano pepper, seeded and quartered
    2 garlic cloves, crushed
    1 lemon zest strip (2 inches)
    1-1/2 cups vodka
    Ice
    GARNISH:	
    Pickled baby beets

Directions:
    1. Place the pepper, garlic, lemon zest and vodka in a large glass or plastic container. Cover and let stand at room temperature for 1 week.
    2. For each serving, fill a shaker three-fourths full with ice. Add 1-1/2 ounces infused vodka to shaker; cover and shake until condensation forms on outside of shaker, 10-15 seconds. Strain into a chilled martini glass. Garnish with a beet.

Vampire Survivors: A Bite-Sized Masterpiece
Rating: ★★★★★
_____________________________

The core gameplay loop of battling through waves of enemies in procedurally generated levels is deceptively simple yet incredibly addictive. The variety of playable characters each with unique abilities adds depth to the strategy, ensuring that each run feels fresh and exciting. The balance between risk and reward, especially when choosing upgrades, keeps you on your toes and constantly engaged.

The pixel art style is both charming and functional, providing a clear and visually appealing backdrop for the chaos that unfolds on the screen. The game's simplicity doesn't sacrifice its aesthetic appeal, and the enemy designs add a delightful touch to the overall atmosphere.

The progression system, where you unlock new characters and abilities over time, adds a layer of long-term engagement. It strikes a perfect balance, encouraging players to keep coming back for more without feeling overly grindy.

In conclusion, Vampire Survivors is a testament to the beauty of indie game design. It takes a simple concept and executes it flawlessly, delivering an addictive and rewarding experience. Whether you're a fan of roguelites or just looking for a game that's easy to pick up and play, Vampire Survivors deserves a spot in your library. It's a solid 5/5 in my book—a true testament to the joy it brings to players.

I ironed a shirt.  Nothing happened.

In all seriousness though, if you are REALLY on the fence about this game like I was, you'll be disappointed at first and wonder why you spent that money for just 4 levels with potato graphics and potato story.  Then you'll discover a bunch of global upgrades and unlocks (including more levels - but the graphics and story remain potato), you'll figure out your favorite combos, and become a true force to be reckoned with as you fill the screen with evolved weapons fire to the point you can hardly see anything happening.  If all goes well, the game loop mostly turns into a Sitting Simulator around the 22 minute mark...every loop.  You vacuumed up thousands of gems and applied 50 or so upgrades.  You worked hard for the moment.  So let that addicting dopamine rush settle in.  Then repeat it all again until 2 am.  The best part of this game is you can play as little as a single 15 or 30 minute round (depending on the level) and the RNG aspects are generally quite decent (i.e. it's rare to fail due to bad RNG).

I'm absolutely hooked on Vampire Survivors! Even without a discount, this game is worth every penny. The addition of couch mode has turned my gaming sessions into epic local multiplayer showdowns – it's a game-changer. The pixel art style brings back fond memories of classic arcades, and the game play is just as addictive. My only wish? Online multiplayer to take the fun global and a high-score screen for that extra nostalgia kick. But even without those, Vampire Survivors is an absolute treasure, and I can't wait to see what updates are in store. It's a keeper!

↑ This is me reviewing the early access of the game. 

And now, we're here, on the official release on the game. I really like the game ever since I bought it since February (It wasn't even on sale, but the $3 I spent here was totally worth it). You really become the bullet hell on this, simple game, and the only thing you do is to move (and sometimes dodge), pick up chests and select your weapons/items. By playing this game, you will never realized how much time did you waste playing on this game, and I like it. This would be my best game of 2022, because of the soundtrack, as well as the effort on delivering updates in either every 2 weeks or a month since early access.

Edit: I noticed yesterday, the mobile version of this game has been already released like a week ago. Now, we can play Vampire Survivors literally anywhere with your phone (except save files from PC to mobile isn't possible). Apart from that, just, damn, I really love this game, and also how amazing this people are.

I generally like this genre of games.

[b]Vampire Survivors is phenomenal game[/b]. Rather dull at first glance. But becomes [i]much deeper, brighter, more complex and exciting[/i] as you play. And several hours after – there's no turning back. 😐

For just a few bucks, the game offers lots of content: the number of [i]weapons, passives and characters[/i] – as well as [i]ultimate evolutions[/i] obtaining through their combination – is incredible.

The game is [i]very stingy with lore[/i], disclosing it only in shards. So most of the time you can't tell exactly what are you doing or why, feeling like a dog chasing cars. But this is just making it more attractive.

There's [i]lots of secret gaming content[/i] as well. For example, at the given stage of a session there's the Reaper appears and instantly kills your character. Seems like an end, right? Well, yes. [i]But no[/i]. 😁 The Reaper can be defeated under certain conditions. And not only that: if you do it, the Reaper becomes available as a playable character! [i]Isn't it fascinating?![/i] 😱

The developers continue to [i]actively update and expand[/i] their creation. Two DLCs have been released at the moment; each of them has its own theme, adds a [i]very detailed and atmospheric stages[/i] (with new enemies, quests, items) as well as [i]several unique characters and abilities[/i]. Overall they feels like a breath of fresh air.

[i]The co-op update[/i] forced me to play the game with my wife. She's not a gamer type, you know; but we tried co-op a few times. And now on launching Vampire Survivors I always hear something like [i]What do you think you doin', sumbitch?! Gimme the gamepad![/i] 😁 Love her; it's great fun to play together.

Surely can't insist; but [i]consider the game[/i].
[i]This might be just what you need at the end of a long day.[/i] 😉

Title: Vampire Survivors - A Thrilling Roguelike Experience

Introduction:
Vampire Survivors is an exciting roguelike game that offers a unique and addictive gameplay experience. With its minimalistic design and bullet hell mechanics, this game will keep you engaged for hours on end. Dive into a world filled with challenging enemies, powerful weapons, and strategic decision-making. Here's why Vampire Survivors deserves a spot in your gaming library.

Engaging Gameplay:
Vampire Survivors combines the intensity of a bullet hell game with roguelike elements, creating a thrilling and challenging experience. As you navigate through simple yet sprawling maps, you'll face waves of ghoulies, ghosties, and other supernatural creatures. The game features a horde mode where you must survive for 30 minutes against increasingly powerful enemies. The shooting mechanics are unique, with each weapon having its own firing pattern influenced by your positioning and that of your enemies.

Weapon Variety and Customization:
One of the standout features of Vampire Survivors is the wide variety of weapons available. Each weapon has its own mechanics, area of effect, fire rate, and damage profile. This diversity encourages players to experiment and find their preferred playstyle. Whether you prefer high-risk, high-reward randomization or a more direct and aggressive approach, there are plenty of options to choose from.

Progression and Unlockables:
Vampire Survivors offers a satisfying progression system that keeps you engaged and motivated. With each run, you'll earn gold that can be used to purchase upgrades and help future survivors. The game also features a range of unlockable characters, challenges, and levels, adding depth and replayability to the experience. Discovering hidden secrets and overcoming seemingly invulnerable bosses provides a sense of accomplishment and excitement.

Accessibility and Multiplayer:
Vampire Survivors is designed to be accessible to a wide range of players. It supports various input methods, including mouse, keyboard, controller, and touch screen, allowing you to play the game in your preferred way. Additionally, the local co-op for up to 4 players enhances the game's social aspect, making it a great choice for multiplayer sessions.

Conclusion:
Vampire Survivors is a hidden gem in the roguelike genre, offering a unique and addictive gameplay experience. With its engaging mechanics, diverse weapon selection, and satisfying progression system, this game is a must-play for fans of bullet hell and roguelike games. Don't miss out on the opportunity to immerse yourself in this thrilling adventure.

writing this after my first pass over the game, where I've gone through all the vanilla stages and unlocked all the relics, [spoiler] killed death [/spoiler], and unlocked a bunch of secret characters. i will play a million more hours but since I've pretty much beaten the base game, here's my thoughts on it:

its so simple that it really SHOULDNT be fun. I'm able to fully plan out my run and then execute my dream build perfectly, but the slot machine RNG dopamine drip of getting those items makes it interesting and engaging every time??? somehow??? well not really *somehow*, I know it's because this game is playable cocaine dressed as a game dressed as a slot machine

 it's so addictive that once I start a run i CANNOT stop until I finish the whole thing,, though my only issue is that unlocking the evo weps is really annoying without a guide, because you're just guessing at combinations. and if you guess wrong, well then I'm playing the next half hour with sub optimal weapons, which isn't that fun.

i love how innovative the game is when they REMOVED skipped manual shooting and focused hard on making the weapon progression super satisfying, they NAILED it. the high point of the game is definitely unlocking new mechanics in each of the base stages, that HOOKED me so hard, and its like each new relic totally redefines the game

Vampire Survivors is an exciting game; despite its simplicity, it keeps me engaged with its replayability. The gameplay is dynamic and strategic, making each playthrough an enjoyable experience. The continuous updates and DLCs have expanded the game in mind-blowing ways, offering new challenges and surprises.

However, there are a couple of things that could be improved:

Firstly, the tooltip that appears after opening treasure chests disappears too quickly, and it would be more beneficial if it consistently reappeared, giving players enough time to grasp the information.

Additionally, customizable navigation arrows for items would be a valuable improvement, allowing players to adjust their size or color scheme for better visibility during intense moments.

There seems to be an FPS-related issue, as the hero can pass through objects like middle libraries, pianos, or even the boundaries of water and forest when the areas are crowded with enemies, affecting the overall experience.

Lastly, while the opening animations for treasure chests add excitement, having a toggle option to skip or increase the animation speed, particularly for epic and legendary chests, would address varying player preferences and streamline the overall experience.

Great game to go into zen state with. Easy to learn, pleasant to play. 

Ton of content to complete and there's always a goal to chase next. Now with a steam deck probably one of the best games to play on the go.

-> Chill game well worth the low price.
-> Lots of casual entertainment you can get out of it.
-> Perfect to hop in for a round or two every now and then.
-> Doesn't ask/force you to spend any more or less time in it than you want to.
-> Doesn't extort you through microtransactions.
-> Doesn't extort you through battlepasses.
-> Doesn't tease you with login rewards. (so no fear of missing out)
-> Doesn't tease you with timed events. (so no fear of missing out)
-> DLCs are optional, cheap and add lots more replay value... but not required.
-> Base game has loads of replayable and unique content along with secrets.
-> Plenty of achievements ranging from easy to hard to get.
-> Ingame earnable cosmetics and a well tailored sense of progression.
-> Overall control scheme is simple to get into and master.
-> Retro look gives a warm and casual feeling to the game.
-> Soundtrack is surprisingly awesome. (seriously, I'm not kidding)
-> Updates and new features rolled out regularly still.
-> Now with co-op.

I could just go on and on, there's not a single bad thing I can say about this game even though I'm not much into retro gaming. It's well worth the price even if you're not sure you'll like it.

Gameplay : 10/10 (Move, avoid enemies, find secrets, challenge yourself with different build, what a pleasant ride)
Story : 6/10 (The lore of each enemies and characters is nice bit of reading, but no main story per say)
Music : 10/10 (Each level got it's music and there a remix if you add different modifier, perfect!)
Graphic : 8/10 (8 Bits of pure pixely mess when get strong enough, but that's the point!)
Replayability : 10/10 (Try to finish all level with all characters, you'll dig so deeps in the hours that it will turn to weeks.)

Pro
- Lot's of enemies and way to play, but when you find your build you'll mostly stick to it.
- Lot's of free updates and DLC content, never had a boring moment whit this game.

Con
- No Vampires

The developers are like the cool parents who keep throwing surprise parties - updates keep rolling in, making me question if this game is commitment or a life long relationship. All this fun for the price of a cup of coffee? I haven't been frugal since my last steam sale binge. Get ready for a "pixel'icious" time - just be prepared to explain to your boss why you haven't slept in a week.
